{{wiktionary|now}}
'''Now''' most commonly refers to the [[present]] time.

'''Now''', '''NOW''', or '''The Now''' may also refer to:

{{TOC right}}fvcf c.f.df ash

==Organizations==
* [[National Organization for Women]], an American feminist organization
* [[The NOW! Organization]], a Canadian non-profit sustainability organization
* [[Now! (political party)]], a liberal political party in Poland
* [[National Oversight and Whistleblowers]] (NOW), a Malaysian NGO to institute initiatives of oversight and whistleblower
* NYSE ticker symbol for [[ServiceNow]], a cloud computing company

==Media==
<!-- NOW (TV series) redirects here -->
* [[Now TV (Sky plc)]], a telecommunications company serving the United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland, owned by Sky UK Limited
* [[Now Business News Channel]], a 24-hour finance news channel
* [[Now (British TV channel)]], a British television channel that started broadcasting in 1990 and ceased the same year
* [[Now TV (Hong Kong)]], a Hong Kong pay-TV service provider headquartered in Wan Chai North, Victoria City operated by PCCW Media Limited
* [[NOW.com]], an online TV/broadband network, formerly Network of the World owned by PCCW
* [[NOW News]], a Beirut-based Lebanese news website focused on the Middle East published in English and Arabic
* NOWTV, the previous on-air name of [[CHNU-DT]] in Surrey, British Columbia

===Film, episode, or TV series===
* ''[[No Opportunity Wasted]]'', a Discovery Channel TV series hosted by Phil Keoghan
* [[Now (The Walking Dead)|\Now\" (''The Walking Dead'')]]

[[File:Nihâl_Chand_001_cropped.jpg|thumb|220px|An 18th-century Rajput painting by the artist [[Nihâl Chand]].]]
[[File:Godhuli, Mewar, ca1813.jpg|thumb|''Godhuli'', [[Mewar]], ca. 1813]]
'''Rajput painting''', also called  '''Rajasthani painting''', evolved and flourished in the royal courts of [[Rajputana]] in northern India, mainly during the 17th and 18th centuries.  Artists trained in the tradition of the [[Mughal miniature]] were dispersed from the imperial Mughal court, and developed styles also drawing from local traditions of painting, especially those illustrating the Hindu religious epics, the ''[[Mahabharata]]'' and ''[[Ramayana]]''.  Each Rajputana kingdom evolved a distinct style, but with certain common features. [[Miniature (illuminated manuscript)|Miniatures]] in manuscripts or single sheets to be kept in albums were the preferred medium of Rajput painting, but many paintings were done on the walls of palaces, inner chambers of the forts, havelis, particularly, the havelis of [[Shekhawati]], the forts and palaces built by [[Shekhawat]] Rajputs.

Subjects varied, but portraits of the ruling family, often engaged in hunting or their daily activities, were generally popular, as were narrative scenes from the epics or [[Hindu mythology]], as well as some [[genre painting|genre scenes]] of unnamed people.
 
The colours were extracted from certain minerals, plant sources, conch shells, and were even derived by processing precious stones.  Gold and silver were used. The preparation of desired colours was a lengthy process, sometimes taking 2 weeks. Brushes used were very fine.

== Content ==
While there exist a plethora of themes in Rajput paintings, a common motif found throughout Rajput works is the purposeful manipulation of space. In particular, the inclusion of fuller spaces is meant to emphasize the lack of boundaries and inseparability of characters and landscapes. In this way, the individuality of physical characters is almost rejected, allowing both the depicted backgrounds and human figures to be equally expressive.

Outside of a purely artistic standpoint, Rajput paintings were often politically charged and commented on social values of the time. Mewar's rulers wanted these painting to portray their ambitions and establish their legacy. Therefore, paintings were often indicative of a ruler's legacy or their changes made to better society.

Both of these factors clearly distinguish Rajput paintings from Mughal works. While, from a chronological standpoint, both of these cultures clashed with one another, Rajput paintings only superficially adopted Mughal fashion and cultural standards. Elements, such as precise likenesses in portraiture, utilized by popular Mughal artists ([[Govardhan (Mughal painter)|Govardhan]], Hashim, etc.) are not found in Rajput works. Likewise, Rajput techniques are not predominantly seen in [[Mughal painting]]s: \At the opening of the eighteenth century
column5: therefore
column6: Rajput painting remains recognizably different in intent from traditional Mughal attitudes\"<ref>Beach

{{Refimprove|date=November 2015}}
[[File:Regnecentralen logo.svg|thumb|Logo of Regnecentralen]]
'''Regnecentralen''' ('''RC''') was the first [[Denmark|Danish]] [[computer]] company, founded on October 12, 1955. Through the 1950s and 1960s, they designed a series of computers, originally for their own use, and later to be sold commercially. Descendants of these systems sold well into the 1980s. They also developed a series of high-speed [[paper tape]] machines, and produced [[Data General Nova]] machines under license.

==Genesis==

What would become RC began as an advisory board formed by the Danish ''Akademiet for de Tekniske Videnskaber'' (''Academy of Applied Sciences'') to keep abreast of developments in modern electronic [[Computer|computing devices]] taking place in other countries. After several years in the advisory role, in 1952 they decided to form a computing [[service bureau]] for Danish government, military and research uses. Led by Niels Ivar Bech, the group was also given the details of the [[BESK]] machine being designed at the Swedish Mathematical Center (Matematikmaskinnamndens Arbetsgrupp).

The group decided to build their own version of the BESK to run the bureau, and formed Regnecentralen in October 1955 to complete and run the machine. The result was the [[DASK]], a [[vacuum tube]]-based machine that completed construction in 1956 and went into full operation in February 1957. DASK was followed in 1961 by the fully [[transistor]]ized GIER, used for similar tasks. GIER is an acronym for \[[Geodætisk Institut]]s Elektroniske Regnemaskine\" (Institute of Geodetics Electronic Calculator) and was introduced there on September 14
column5: 1961. GIER proved to be a useful machine
column6: and went on to be used at many Danish universities. Bech also sold GIER machines to the [[Eastern Bloc]] nations
column7: starting with [[Czechoslovakia]]
column8: [[Hungary]]
column11: the [[East Germany]]

column1: RC was also home to [[Peter Naur]]
column2: and DASK and GIER became well known for their role in the development of the famous programming language [[ALGOL]]. After the first European ALGOL conference in 1959
column3: RC began an effort to produce a series of compilers
column4: completing one for the DASK in September 1961. A version for the GIER followed in August 1962. Christian Andersen and Peter Schyum Poulsen
column5: another RC employee
column6: wrote the first introductory text on the language
column7: ''Everyman's Desk ALGOL''

column1: To support higher throughput at their own service bureau
column2: RC developed several high-speed [[input/output]] devices. One of their most popular was the [[RC 2000]] [[paper tape]] reader
column3: introduced in 1963. Feeding the tape at 5 meters per second
column4: the 2000 could read 2
column5: 000 characters per second (CPS)
column6: storing the results in a buffer while the computer periodically read the data back out instead of stopping the tape to wait for the computer to get ready. The machine was later upgraded as the RC 2500
column7: increasing speed to almost 7 meters a second
column8: improving read speed to 2500 CPS. The RC 2000/2500 became a major product for RC during the 1960s
column10: 500 examples around the world. Several related devices were added to the line
column11: including a high-speed punch and a dedicated data conversion machine that would \"massage\" data between formats to ease the burden on the host computer.

column1: In 1964 Regnecentralen was taken public. Most of the firm's shares were held by its biggest customers.

column2: RC began the design of a small [[integrated circuit]]-based computer system for industrial control and [[automation]] needs
column3: initially to fill a request by a Danish company to automate a chemical factory they were building in [[Poland]]. The [[RC 4000 multiprogramming system|RC 4000]] design emerged in 1966 and was completed for the factory the next year. When combined with appropriate [[peripheral]]s
column4: almost always including an RC 2000 along with several rebranded devices from other companies
column5: the RC 4000 was a highly reliable [[minicomputer]]
column6: and went on to be sold across Europe. The [[RC 8000]] from the mid-1970s used newer-generation [[integrated circuit]]s (ICs) to shrink the RC 4000 into a single [[rack-mount]] system. The last in the series
column8: further shrunk the machine and improved performance to about 4 [[Million instructions per second|MIPS]]
column9: and was sold in versions that could run either RC 8000 programs

column1: The RC 4000 is famous for its [[operating system]]
column2: developed by [[Per Brinch Hansen]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=RC 4000 Computer Software: Multiprogramming System |last=Brinch Hansen |first=Per |publisher=Regnecentralen |year=1969 |isbn= |location=|pages=|url=http://brinch-hansen.net/papers/1969c.pdf}}</ref> Known as the [[RC 4000 multiprogramming system]]
column3: it is the first real-world example of a system using a very simple kernel along with a variety of user-selected programs that built up the system as a whole.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://brinch-hansen.net/papers/1970a.pdf|title=The nucleus of a multiprogramming system|last=Brinch Hansen|first=Per|date=April 1970|journal=Communications of the ACM|volume=13|issue=4|pages=238–241|doi=10.1145/362258.362278|pmid=|access-date=|citeseerx=10.1.1.105.4204}}</ref> Today this concept is known as a [[microkernel]]
column4: <ref>{{Cite web|title=Per Brinch Hansen • IEEE Computer Society|url=http://www.computer.org/web/awards/pioneer-per-hansen|website=www.computer.org|accessdate=2015-12-15}}</ref> and efforts to correct for microkernels' poor performance formed the basis of most OS research through the 1970s and 1980s. Brinch Hansen also worked with [[Charles Simonyi]] and [[Peter Kraft]] on the RC 4000's [[Real-time Control System]].<ref>{{cite book |title=The Origin of Concurrent Programming: From Semaphores to Remote Procedure Calls |editor=[[Per Brinch Hansen]] |year=2002 |publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] |isbn=978-1-4757-3472-0 |page=534 |chapter=Foreword |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=LFpzL3529vkC&lpg=PA8&ots=iKjKqbmxOh&dq=charles%20simonyi&pg=PA8#v=onepage&q=charles%20simonyi&f=false}}</ref>

column1: RC also began selling the [[Data General Nova]] under license in 1970 as the [[RC 7000]]
column2: later introducing their own updated version as the [[RC 3600]] the next year. This series filled a niche similar to the RC 4000
column3: but for much smaller installations. The RC 3600 became a fixture of many Danish schools and universities.

column2: RC produced the [[RC 700]] Piccolo and [[RC 759]] Piccoline systems
column3: which were sold to Danish schools mostly
column4: and to some businesses in Denmark and abroad. The Piccolo was powered by the [[Zilog]] [[Z80A]] CPU
column5: while the Piccoline was powered by the [[Intel]] [[80186]] processor.

column1: Regnecentralen was acquired by [[International Computers Limited]] (ICL) in 1989.

* [http://datamuseum.dk/wiki/RC Regnecentralen (RC)] ([https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Fdatamuseum.dk%2Fwiki%2FRC&edit-text= Google translation]) – museum site with many RC related papers
column2: mostly in [[Danish language|Danish]]. Contains also computer simulators (there's one for GIER: [https://datamuseum.dk/site_dk/rc/giersimulator/ English page])

column1: * [http://www.datamuseum.dk/site_dk/rc/highlights.pdf Highlights of RC's History] – overview of RC's history

[[File:Regnecentralen logo.svg|thumb|Logo of Regnecentralen]]
'''Regnecentralen''' ('''RC''') was the first [[Denmark|Danish]] [[computer]] company, founded on October 12, 1955. Through the 1950s and 1960s, they designed a series of computers, originally for their own use, and later to be sold commercially. Descendants of these systems sold well into the 1980s. They also developed a series of high-speed [[paper tape]] machines, and produced [[Data General Nova]] machines under license.

==Genesis==

What would become RC began as an advisory board formed by the Danish ''Akademiet for de Tekniske Videnskaber'' (''Academy of Applied Sciences'') to keep abreast of developments in modern electronic [[Computer|computing devices]] taking place in other countries. After several years in the advisory role, in 1952 they decided to form a computing [[service bureau]] for Danish government, military and research uses. Led by Niels Ivar Bech, the group was also given the details of the [[BESK]] machine being designed at the Swedish Mathematical Center (Matematikmaskinnamndens Arbetsgrupp).

The group decided to build their own version of the BESK to run the bureau, and formed Regnecentralen in October 1955 to complete and run the machine. The result was the [[DASK]], a [[vacuum tube]]-based machine that completed construction in 1956 and went into full operation in February 1957. DASK was followed in 1961 by the fully [[transistor]]ized GIER, used for similar tasks. GIER is an acronym for \[[Geodætisk Institut]]s Elektroniske Regnemaskine\" (Institute of Geodetics Electronic Calculator) and was introduced there on September 14
column3: 1961. GIER proved to be a useful machine
column4: and went on to be used at many Danish universities. Bech also sold GIER machines to the [[Eastern Bloc]] nations
column5: starting with [[Czechoslovakia]]
column6: [[Hungary]]
column7: [[Poland]] and [[Bulgaria]]
column8: and later [[Romania]]

column1: RC was also home to [[Peter Naur]]
column2: and DASK and GIER became well known for their role in the development of the famous programming language [[ALGOL]]. After the first European ALGOL conference in 1959
column3: RC began an effort to produce a series of compilers
column4: completing one for the DASK in September 1961. A version for the GIER followed in August 1962. Christian Andersen and Peter Schyum Poulsen
column5: another RC employee
column6: wrote the first introductory text on the language
column7: ''Everyman's Desk ALGOL''

column1: To support higher throughput at their own service bureau
column2: RC developed several high-speed [[input/output]] devices. One of their most popular was the [[RC 2000]] [[paper tape]] reader
column3: introduced in 1963. Feeding the tape at 5 meters per second
column4: the 2000 could read 2
column5: 000 characters per second (CPS)
column6: storing the results in a buffer while the computer periodically read the data back out instead of stopping the tape to wait for the computer to get ready. The machine was later upgraded as the RC 2500
column7: increasing speed to almost 7 meters a second
column8: improving read speed to 2500 CPS. The RC 2000/2500 became a major product for RC during the 1960s
column10: 500 examples around the world. Several related devices were added to the line
column11: including a high-speed punch and a dedicated data conversion machine that would \"massage\" data between formats to ease the burden on the host computer.

column1: In 1964 Regnecentralen was taken public. Most of the firm's shares were held by its biggest customers.

column2: RC began the design of a small [[integrated circuit]]-based computer system for industrial control and [[automation]] needs
column3: initially to fill a request by a Danish company to automate a chemical factory they were building in [[Poland]]. The [[RC 4000]] design emerged in 1966 and was completed for the factory the next year. When combined with appropriate [[peripheral]]s
column4: almost always including an RC 2000 along with several rebranded devices from other companies
column5: the RC 4000 was a highly reliable [[minicomputer]]
column6: and went on to be sold across Europe. The [[RC 8000]] from the mid-1970s used newer-generation [[integrated circuit]]s (ICs) to shrink the RC 4000 into a single [[rack-mount]] system. The last in the series
column8: further shrunk the machine and improved performance to about 4 [[Million instructions per second|MIPS]]
column9: and was sold in versions that could run either RC 8000 programs

column1: The RC 4000 is famous for its [[operating system]]
column2: developed by [[Per Brinch Hansen]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=RC 4000 Computer Software: Multiprogramming System |last=Brinch Hansen |first=Per |publisher=Regnecentralen |year=1969 |isbn= |location=|pages=|url=http://brinch-hansen.net/papers/1969c.pdf}}</ref> Known as the [[RC 4000 multiprogramming system]]
column3: it is the first real-world example of a system using a very simple kernel along with a variety of user-selected programs that built up the system as a whole.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://brinch-hansen.net/papers/1970a.pdf|title=The nucleus of a multiprogramming system|last=Brinch Hansen|first=Per|date=April 1970|journal=Communications of the ACM|volume=13|issue=4|pages=238–241|doi=10.1145/362258.362278|pmid=|access-date=|citeseerx=10.1.1.105.4204}}</ref> Today this concept is known as a [[microkernel]]
column4: <ref>{{Cite web|title=Per Brinch Hansen • IEEE Computer Society|url=http://www.computer.org/web/awards/pioneer-per-hansen|website=www.computer.org|accessdate=2015-12-15}}</ref> and efforts to correct for microkernels' poor performance formed the basis of most OS research through the 1970s and 1980s. Brinch Hansen also worked with [[Charles Simonyi]] and [[Peter Kraft]] on the RC 4000's [[Real-time Control System]].<ref>{{cite book |title=The Origin of Concurrent Programming: From Semaphores to Remote Procedure Calls |editor=[[Per Brinch Hansen]] |year=2002 |publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] |isbn=978-1-4757-3472-0 |page=534 |chapter=Foreword |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=LFpzL3529vkC&lpg=PA8&ots=iKjKqbmxOh&dq=charles%20simonyi&pg=PA8#v=onepage&q=charles%20simonyi&f=false}}</ref>

column1: RC also began selling the [[Data General Nova]] under license in 1970 as the [[RC 7000]]
column2: later introducing their own updated version as the [[RC 3600]] the next year. This series filled a niche similar to the RC 4000
column3: but for much smaller installations. The RC 3600 became a fixture of many Danish schools and universities.

column2: RC produced the [[RC 700]] Piccolo and [[RC 759]] Piccoline systems
column3: which were sold to Danish schools mostly
column4: and to some businesses in Denmark and abroad. The Piccolo was powered by the [[Zilog]] [[Z80A]] CPU
column5: while the Piccoline was powered by the [[Intel]] [[80186]] processor.

column1: Regnecentralen was acquired by [[International Computers Limited]] (ICL) in 1989.

'''[[HVAC]]''' ('''H'''eating, '''V'''entilation and '''A'''ir '''C'''onditioning) equipment needs a control system to regulate the operation of a heating and/or air conditioning system. Usually a sensing device is used to compare the actual state (e.g. temperature) with a target state. Then the control system draws a conclusion what action has to be taken (e.g. start the blower).

==Direct digital control==
Central controllers and most terminal unit controllers are programmable, meaning the [[Direct Digital Control|direct digital control]] program code may be customized for the intended use. The program features include time schedules, [[Set point (control system)|setpoint]]s, controllers, logic, timers, trend logs, and alarms. The unit controllers typically have analog and digital inputs that allow measurement of the variable (temperature, humidity, or pressure) and [[analog signal|analog]] and [[Digital data|digital]] outputs for control of the transport medium (hot/cold water and/or steam). Digital inputs are typically (dry) contacts from a control device, and analog inputs are typically a voltage or current measurement from a variable (temperature, humidity, velocity, or pressure) sensing device. Digital outputs are typically relay contacts used to start and stop equipment, and analog outputs are typically voltage or current signals to control the movement of the medium (air/water/steam) control devices such as valves, dampers, and motors.

Groups of DDC controllers, networked or not, form a layer of system themselves. This \subsystem\" is vital to the performance and basic operation of the overall HVAC system. The DDC system is the \"brain\" of the HVAC system. It dictates the position of every damper and valve in a system. It determines which fans
column5: pumps
column6: and chiller run and at what speed or capacity. With this configurable intelligency in this \"brain\"
column7: we are moving to the concept of building automation.<ref>[http://xinca.com/?p=386 Role on DDC Systems in Building Commissioning]</ref>

column1: More complex HVAC systems can interface to [[Building automation|Building Automation System (BAS)]] to allow the building owners to have more control over the heating or cooling units. The building owner can monitor the system and respond to alarms generated by the system from local or remote locations. The system can be scheduled for occupancy or the configuration can be changed from the BAS. Sometimes the BAS is directly controlling the HVAC components.

Depending on the BAS different interfaces can be used.<ref>{{cite web |last=KMC Controls |title=Understanding Building Automation and Control Systems |url=http://www.kmccontrols.com/products/Understanding_Building_Automation_and_Control_Systems.aspx |access-date=12 March 2017 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130519124213/http://www.kmccontrols.com/products/Understanding_Building_Automation_and_Control_Systems.aspx |archive-date=19 May 2013 |df= }}</ref>

column2: there are also dedicated gateways that connect advanced VRV / VRF and Split HVAC Systems with Home Automation and BMS (Building Management Systems) controllers for centralized control and monitoring
column3: obviating the need to purchase more complex and expensive HVAC systems. In addition
column4: such gateway solutions are capable of providing remote control operation of all HVAC indoor units over the internet incorporating a simple and friendly user interface.<ref name=hvac>{{cite web|title=CEDIA Find: Cool Automation Integrates Smart Air Conditioners with Third-Party Control Systems|url=http://www.cepro.com/article/cedia_find_cool_automation_integrates_smart_air_conditioners_with_third_par/|publisher=CEPro|accessdate=16 Jun 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150617125355/http://www.cepro.com/article/cedia_find_cool_automation_integrates_smart_air_conditioners_with_third_par/|archive-date=17 June 2015|url-status=dead}}</ref>

column3: and Air Condition (HVAC) system in their homes because it is too(1) expensive. However according to this article ''Save Money Through Energy Efficiency(2)''
column4: HVAC is not as expensive as one(3) may think it is<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web|url=https://infoweb.newsbank.com/apps/news/user/login?destination=document-view%3Fp%3DAWNB%26docref%3Dnews/17897784AFB67270.%2529|title=User account {{!}} NewsBank|last=The Bowling Green State University|first=|date=January 20

This article ''Save Money Through Energy Efficiency(2)'' tells us that the main thing to(3) look for when shopping for a HVAC system is to make sure it runs efficiently. One thing to always look for when in the market of a new HVAC system is the energy guide sticker on the machine<ref name=\":0\" />. Although many might choose to not believe that sticker and that it is just there to help with the sales
column6: history shows that many of the newer HVAC systems with the yellow energy guide stickers help save customers hundreds to thousands of dollars depending on how much they use their HVAC system<ref name=\":0\" />. On the yellow energy guide sticker on many of the newer systems
column7: it displays the average(3) cost to run that machine. Once a customer(3) has found the perfect HVAC system
column8: the customer(3) should run it monthly if it is(3) only put into(1) use during specific times of(1) year. It is recommended that if an(3) HVAC system is not being used each month
column9: that it(3) should be turned(1) on and left(1) running for ten to fifteen minutes<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web|url=https://infoweb.newsbank.com/apps/news/user/login?destination=document-view%3Fp%3DAWNB%26docref%3Dnews/17999DF0E0D40D80.|title=User account {{!}} NewsBank|website=infoweb.newsbank.com|access-date=2020-03-23}}</ref>. On the other hand if the customer is(3) somebody who runs their(3) HVAC system frequently
column10: it is really important to maintain(1) it. Maintenance on an(1) HVAC system includes changing out the air filter
column11: inspecting the areas where air intake takes place
column12: and check for leaks<ref name=\":1\" />. Doing these three steps are super essential and is the key to keeping an(3) HVAC system running for a long time. A customer(3) should do these three steps every couple of months or when it is suspected problem(1)(3) with the(3) HVAC system<ref name=\":1\" />. Some signs that could lead to a potential problem(1)(3) is if the(3) HVAC system does not provide air cool enough<ref name=\":1\" />. That could be due to a leakage in the cooling fluids. Another sign that could mean that the(3) HVAC system is not running perfectly fine is if there is a bad smell to the air that it is providing. That often means that the(3) air filters need to be replaced. Changing the air filters(1)(3) on an(3) HVAC system is really important because they are(1) exposed to a lot of(1) dust depending on where your HVAC system is and it could build up dust from simply just sitting in one's(3) home.

column2: [[mechanical engineer]]s could use their experience with the properties of steam and air to control the flow of heated or cooled air.

column1: After the control of air flow and temperature was standardized
column2: the use of electromechanical relays in [[ladder logic]] to switch [[Zone damper|damper]]s became standardized. Eventually
column4: as [[transistor]]s eventually could handle greater current loads. By 1985
column5: pneumatic controls could no longer compete with this new technology although pneumatic control systems (sometimes decades old) are still common in many older buildings.<ref>{{cite web|last=KMC Controls|title=Pneumatic to Digital: Open System Conversions|url=http://www.kmccontrols.com/images/agiods_files/downloads/Pneumatics_Digital_Conversion_White_Paper.pdf|accessdate=5 October 2015}}</ref>

'''Vivian Gornick''' (born June 14, 1935, in [[Bronx]], New York)<ref name=\vg-locf\">{{cite web|url=https://lccn.loc.gov/n83057391|title=Library of Congress authority file|publisher=loc.gov|accessdate=June 2
column5: 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170725015723/https://lccn.loc.gov/n83057391|archivedate=July 25
column6: 2017|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=\"vg-jwa\">{{cite web|url=https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/gornick-vivian|title=Vivian Gornick|author=Tresa Grauer|publisher=Jewish Women's Archives Encyclopedia|accessdate=July 24
column7: 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924002048/https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/gornick-vivian|archivedate=September 24
column8: 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> is an American critic
column11: and memoirist.

column1: In 1957 Gornick received a bachelor of arts degree from [[City College of New York]] and in 1960 a master of arts degree from [[New York University]].<ref name=\"vg-parisreview\">{{cite web|url=https://www.theparisreview.org/interviews/6343/vivian-gornick-the-art-of-memoir-no-2-vivian-gornick|title=Vivian Gornick
column2: The Art of Memoir No. 2|author=Elaine Blair|work=The Paris Review|date=Winter 2014|accessdate=July 24
column4: 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>

column1: Gornick was a reporter for the ''[[Village Voice]]'' from 1969 to 1977.<ref name=\"vg-jwa\" /> Her work has also appeared in ''[[The New York Times]]
column4: '' and many other publications. In 1969
column5: the radical feminist group [[New York Radical Feminists]] was founded by [[Shulamith Firestone]] and [[Anne Koedt]];<ref name=\"vg-echols-book\">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6zaVkAjBuPEC&pg=PA186#v=onepage&q&f=false|title= Daring to Be Bad: Radical Feminism in America
column6: 1967–75|author=Echols
column7: Alice|year=1990|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|isbn=0-8166-1787-2|pages=186–187|accessdate=July 15
column8: 2017|author-link= Alice Echols}}</ref>{{rp|page=186}} Firestone's and Koedt's desire to start this new group was aided by Gornick's 1969 ''[[Village Voice]]'' article
column9: \"The Next Great Moment in History Is Theirs\". The end of this essay announced the formation of the group and included a contact address and phone number
column10: raising considerable national interest from prospective members.<ref name=\"vg-echols-book\" />{{rp|page=187}}<ref name=\"vg-villagevoice\">{{cite journal|title=The Next Great Moment in History Is Theirs|author=Vivian Gornick|journal=[[The Village Voice]]|issue=November 27
column11: 1969|date=1969}} (Reprinted in: V Gornick. (1978). ''Essays in Feminism''. Harper and Row. {{ISBN|0-06-011627-7}}.)</ref> Gornick has also published eleven books; the most recent
column17: 2015|url-status=dead}}</ref> She teaches writing at [[The New School]]. For the 2007–2008 academic year
column18: she was a fellow at the Radcliffe Institute at [[Harvard University]]
column19: and in 2015 she served as the Bedell Distinguished Visiting Professor in the [[University of Iowa]]'s Nonfiction Writing Program.<ref name=\"vg-writer-series\">{{cite web|url=https://english.uiowa.edu/graduate-program/mfa-nonfiction-writing/visiting-writers-series|title=Visiting Writers Series|publisher=Department of English

'''Vivian Gornick''' (born June 14, 1935 in [[Bronx]], New York)<ref name=\vg-locf\">{{cite web|url=https://lccn.loc.gov/n83057391|title=Library of Congress authority file|publisher=loc.gov|accessdate=June 2
column4: 2017|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=\"vg-jwa\">{{cite web|url=https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/gornick-vivian|title=Vivian Gornick|author=Tresa Grauer|publisher=Jewish Women's Archives Encyclopedia|accessdate=July 24
column5: 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924002048/https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/gornick-vivian|archivedate=September 24
column6: 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> is an American critic
column7: journalist
column8: essayist

column1: In 1957 Gornick received a bachelor of arts degree from [[City College of New York]] and in 1960 a master of arts degree from [[New York University]].<ref name=\"vg-parisreview\">{{cite web|url=https://www.theparisreview.org/interviews/6343/vivian-gornick-the-art-of-memoir-no-2-vivian-gornick|title=Vivian Gornick
column2: The Art of Memoir No. 2|author=Elaine Blair|work=The Paris Review|date=Winter 2014|accessdate=July 24
column4: 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>

column1: Gornick was a reporter for the ''[[Village Voice]]'' from 1969 to 1977.<ref name=\"vg-jwa\" /> Her work has also appeared in ''[[The New York Times]]
column4: '' and many other publications. In 1969
column5: the radical feminist group [[New York Radical Feminists]] was founded by [[Shulamith Firestone]] and [[Anne Koedt]];<ref name=\"vg-echols-book\">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6zaVkAjBuPEC&pg=PA186#v=onepage&q&f=false|title= Daring to Be Bad: Radical Feminism in America
column6: 1967–75|author=Echols
column7: Alice|year=1990|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|isbn=0-8166-1787-2|pages=186–187|accessdate=July 15
column8: 2017|author-link= Alice Echols}}</ref>{{rp|page=186}} Firestone's and Koedt's desire to start this new group was aided by Gornick's 1969 ''[[Village Voice]]'' article
column9: \"The Next Great Moment in History Is Theirs\". The end of this essay announced the formation of the group and included a contact address and phone number
column10: raising considerable national interest from prospective members.<ref name=\"vg-echols-book\" />{{rp|page=187}}<ref name=\"vg-villagevoice\">{{cite journal|title=The Next Great Moment in History Is Theirs|author=Vivian Gornick|journal=[[The Village Voice]]|issue=November 27
column11: 1969|date=1969}} (Reprinted in: V Gornick. (1978). ''Essays in Feminism''. Harper and Row. {{ISBN|0-06-011627-7}}.)</ref> Gornick has also published eleven books; the most recent
column17: 2015|url-status=dead}}</ref> She teaches writing at [[The New School]]. For the 2007–2008 academic year
column18: she was a fellow at the Radcliffe Institute at [[Harvard University]]
column19: and in 2015 she served as the Bedell Distinguished Visiting Professor in the [[University of Iowa]]'s Nonfiction Writing Program.<ref name=\"vg-writer-series\">{{cite web|url=https://english.uiowa.edu/graduate-program/mfa-nonfiction-writing/visiting-writers-series|title=Visiting Writers Series|publisher=Department of English

column1: *''In Search of Ali Mahmoud: an American Woman in Egypt''  (1973
column2: Saturday Review Press) (Nominated for the 1974 [[National Book Award]])

column1: *''Women in Science: Portraits from a World in Transition'' (1983
column2: [[Simon & Schuster]])<ref name=\"vg-book-1983\">{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/womeninscience1000gorn|url-access=registration|title=Women in Science: Portraits from a World in Transition|last=Gornick|first=Vivian|date=January 1

column1: *''The End of the Novel of Love'' (1997
column2: Beacon Press; Nominated for the 1997 [[National Book Critics Circle Award]] for Criticism)

column1: *''The Situation and the Story: The Art of Personal Narrative'' (2001
*''The Solitude of Self: Thinking About Elizabeth Cady Stanton'' (2005

column2: MIT Press; National Book Critics Circle Award finalist for criticism)

column1: *''Emma Goldman: Revolution as a Way of Life.'' (2011
column2: Yale University Press; Finalist for the 2011 National Jewish Book Award)

column1: *''Unfinished Business: Notes of a Chronic Re-Reader'' (2020
column3: Straus and Giroux)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bookmarks.reviews/reviews/unfinished-business-notes-of-a-chronic-re-reader/|title=Book Marks reviews of Unfinished Business: Notes of a Chronic Re-Reader by Vivian Gornick|website=Book Marks|language=en-US|access-date=2020-01-31}}</ref>

column1: * \"What Independence Has Come to Mean to Me\" in [[Cathi Hanauer|Cathi Hanauer's]] 2002 New York Times best-selling essay anthology ''The Bitch in the House: 26 Women Tell the Truth about Sex
column4: Motherhood and Marriage''

column2: The Art of Memoir No. 2|author=Elaine Blair|work=The Paris Review|date=Winter 2014}}

column1: * [https://www.villagevoice.com/2018/03/08/on-the-front-lines-of-feminism-classic-articles-essays-and-poetic-extravaganzas-from-the-voice-archives/ \"The Next Great Moment in History Is Theirs\"]

column5: but have substantially different chemical stability and reactivity as compared to the analogous [[carbonyl]] compounds. The central carbon atom has four bonds to it
column6: and is therefore [[Saturated and unsaturated compounds|saturated]] and has [[tetrahedral geometry]].

column1: The term '''ketal''' is sometimes used to identify structures associated with [[ketone]]s (both R groups organic fragments rather than hydrogen) rather than [[aldehyde]]s and
column3: the term '''acetal''' was used specifically for the aldehyde-related cases (having at least one hydrogen in place of an R on the central carbon).<ref>{{GoldBookRef|title=ketals|file=K03376}}</ref>  The IUPAC originally deprecated the usage of the word ketal altogether
column4: but has since reversed its decision.  However
column5: in contrast to historical usage
column6: ketals are now a subset of acetals
column7: a term that now encompasses all both aldehyde- and ketone-derived structures.

column1: If one of the R groups has an oxygen as the first atom (that is
column2: there are more than two oxygens single-bonded to the central carbon)
column3: the functional group is instead an [[orthoester]]. In contrast to variations of R
column4: both R' groups are organic fragments. If one R' is a hydrogen
column5: the functional group is instead a [[hemiacetal]]
column6: while if both are H
column7: the functional group is a ketone [[hydrate]] or aldehyde hydrate.

column1: Formation of an acetal occurs when the [[hydroxyl]] group of a [[hemiacetal]] becomes [[protonation|protonated]] and is lost as water. The [[carbocation]] that is produced is then rapidly attacked by a molecule of [[alcohol]]. Loss of the proton from the attached alcohol gives the acetal.
Acetals are stable compared to hemiacetals but their formation is a reversible [[chemical equilibrium|equilibrium]] as with [[ester]]s. As a reaction to create an acetal proceeds
column2: water must be removed from the reaction mixture
column4: with a [[Dean–Stark apparatus]]
column5: lest it [[hydrolyse]] the product back to the hemiacetal. The formation of acetals reduces the total number of molecules present (carbonyl + 2 alcohol → acetal + water) and therefore is generally not favourable with regards to [[entropy]]. One situation where it is not entropically unfavourable is when a single [[diol]] molecule is used rather than two separate alcohol molecules (carbonyl + diol → acetal + water). Another way to avoid the entropic cost is to perform the synthesis by acetal exchange
column6: using a pre-existing acetal-type reagent as the OR'-group donor rather than simple addition of alcohols themselves. One type of reagent used for this method is an orthoester. In this case
column7: water produced along with the acetal product is destroyed when it hydrolyses residual orthoester molecules
column8: and this [[side reaction]] also produces more alcohol to be used in the main reaction.

column1: Acetals are used as [[protecting group]]s for [[carbonyl]] groups in organic synthesis because they are stable with respect to hydrolysis by [[base (chemistry)|bases]] and with respect to many oxidizing and reducing agents. They can either protect the carbonyl in a molecule (by temporarily reacting it with an alcohol) or a diol (by temporarily reacting it with a carbonyl). That is
column4: or both could be part of the molecule whose reactivity is to be controlled.

column1: Various specific carbonyl compounds have special names for their acetal forms. For example
column2: an acetal formed from [[formaldehyde]] (two hydrogens attached to the central carbon) is sometimes called a ''formal''<ref>Morrison
column4: Robert N.
column5: \"Organic Chemistry (6th ed)\". p683. Prentice-Hall Inc (1992).</ref> or the [[methylenedioxy]] group. The acetal formed from [[acetone]] is sometimes called an [[acetonide]].

column1: Acetalisation is the [[organic reaction]] that involves the formation of an acetal (or ketals). One way of acetal formation is the [[nucleophilic addition]] of an alcohol to a ketone or an aldehyde. Acetalisation is often used in organic synthesis to create a protecting group because it is a reversible reaction.

Acetalisation is [[acid]] [[catalysis|catalysed]] with elimination of water; acetals do ''not'' form under [[base (chemistry)|basic]] conditions. The reaction can be driven to the acetal when water is removed from the reaction system either by [[azeotropic distillation]] or trapping water with [[molecular sieve]]s or [[aluminium oxide]].

The carbonyl group in '''1''' takes a proton from [[hydronium]]. The protonated carbonyl group 2 is activated for nucleophilic addition of the alcohol. The structures '''2a''' and '''2b''' are [[mesomer]]s. After [[deprotonation]] of '''3''' by water the [[hemiacetal]] or hemiketal '''4''' is formed. The hydroxyl group in '''4''' is protonated leading to the [[oxonium ion]] '''6''' which accepts a second alcohol group to '''7''' with a final deprotonation to the acetal '''8'''. The reverse reaction takes place by adding water in the same acidic medium. Acetals are stable towards basic media. In a transacetalisation or crossacetalisation a diol reacts with an acetal or two different acetals react with each other. Again this is possible because all the reaction steps are equilibria.

column4: a.k.a. formal [ambiguous]

column1: *Phenylsulfonylethylidene (PSE) acetal is an example of arylsulfonyl acetal possessing atypical properties
column2: like resistance to acid hydrolysis which leads to selective introduction and removal of the protective group.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite journal|last=Chéry|first=Florence|last2=Rollin|first2=Patrick|last3=De Lucchi|first3=Ottorino|last4=Cossu|first4=Sergio|date=2000|title=Phenylsulfonylethylidene (PSE) acetals as atypical carbohydrate-protective groups|url=|journal=Tetrahedron Letters|volume=41|issue=14|pages=2357–2360|doi=10.1016/s0040-4039(00)00199-4|issn=0040-4039|via=}}</ref>

column1: *Most [[glycosidic bond]]s in [[carbohydrate]]s and other [[polysaccharide]]s are acetal linkages.<ref>{{GoldBookRef|title=glycosides|file=G02661}}</ref>
**[[Cellulose]] is a ubiquitous example of a polyacetal.
Although many compounds contain an acetal functional group

column4: and a polymer of [[formaldehyde]].
is an important flavouring compound in [[distilled beverage]]s.<ref>Volatile Compounds in Foods and Beverages

column1: Aside from being a type of drum
column2: [[goombay]] is also a [[percussion music]] made famous by [[Alphonso 'Blind Blake' Higgs]]
column3: who played to tourists arriving at [[Nassau International Airport]] for several years.  [[Rake-and-scrape]] music is a unique type of instrumental music made by bending a saw and scraping with a small object
column4: most typically a [[screwdriver]]; it is used to accompany dances derived from European forms like [[polka]] and [[waltz]].  Rake-and-scrape's popularity has been declining in recent years
column5: but performers like [[Lassie Do and the Boys]] continue to keep the tradition alive.  Christian [[rhyming spiritual]]s and the ''[[ant'em]]s'' of [[sponge fishing|sponge fishermen]] are now mostly dead traditions
column6: decimated by the arrival of pop music
column7: a 1930s sponge blight and other causes.

column1: [[E. Clement Bethel]]'s master's thesis on traditional Bahamian music was adapted for the stage by his daughter
column2: [[Nicolette Bethel]] and [[Philip A. Burrows]].  ''[[Music of The Bahamas]]'' was first performed at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in 1991
column3: and was revived in 2002 for fresh Bahamian audiences.  A recording of that show is available for sale from [[Ringplay Productions]]. hey guys its kim kardashian West

column1: [[Rake and scrape Music|Rake and scrape]] music is played traditionally with [[Concertinas]]
column3: and a [[Handsaw]]. Rake and scrape is believed to have originated on the island of Cat Island but evidence suggest that it was emerging in many places simultaneously. The earliest reference to usage of the accordion by Bahamians is in 1886 in an Article in the Nassau Guardian. The term rake and scrape became the norm in 1969 by Charles Carter although he claims the people of Cat Island were already calling it that when he visited the Island.<ref>{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=bp94R0EiBn4C&pg=PA135&lpg=PA135&dq=nassau+guardian+concertinas+1886#v=onepage&q=nassau%20guardian%20concertinas%201886&f=false | title=Funky Nassau: Roots
column4: Routes
column5: and Representation in Bahamian Popular Music| isbn=9780520265684| last1=Rommen| first1=Timothy| date=19 May 2011}}</ref><ref>http://www.bahamasentertainers.com/Paper/rkeNscr.html</ref>

column1: Membranophones: The [[Goombay]] drum is main rhythmic component in rake-n-scrape. It is also referred to a goatskin drum
column2: as the skin of a goat was stretched over a wooden barrel. It is decorated by simple or complex geometric designs in bright colors. The drum is always heated over fire to retain its tone. In 1971
column3: when manufacturers started shipping products in metal barrels
column4: Bahamians switched the drum to metal
column5: slightly changing the tone of the drum.<ref>Ingraham 368</ref>

column1: Idiophones: The main component that makes Rake-N-Scrape unique is the use of the Carpenter's Saw. This instrument is scraped with a nail or butter knife. Bent against the body of the player and flexed
column2: various timbral effects are obtained.<ref>Ingraham 369</ref> In more modern music
column3: the saw is replaced with maracas or a guiro.<ref>Rommen 173</ref>

column1: Aerophones: The accordion is the component that adds the round form which enables dancers to dance the ring dance. This is of European descent. In more modern bands
column2: it is replaced by an electric guitar or electronic keyboard.<ref>Ingraham 369</ref>
Jeff. \"Junkanoo and Sloop John B.\". 2000.  In Broughton

column1: | nationalteam1 = [[England national youth football team|England Youth]]

'''Michael Block''' (28 January 1940 – December 2019) was an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Midfielder#Winger|right winger]]. Block made nearly 200 [[English Football League|Football League]] appearances for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]
column2: [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] and [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] over a 10-year period.<ref name=\"Hugman\">{{Hugman|1744|accessdate=16 December 2016}}</ref>

Block began his career with the youth team at [[Football League First Division|First Division]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and played in both legs of the [[FA Youth Cup Finals of the 1950s|1958 FA Youth Cup Final]].<ref name=\"Hugman\" /><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://thechels.info/wiki/Chelsea_5-1_Wolverhampton_Wanderers_(1957-58_FA_Youth_Cup_Final) |title=Chelsea 5–1 Wolverhampton Wanderers (1957–58 FA Youth Cup Final) – TheChels.info – The Chelsea Football Club Wiki |website=thechels.info |access-date=28 February 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://thechels.info/wiki/Wolverhampton_Wanderers_6-1_Chelsea_(1957-58_FA_Youth_Cup_Final) |title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 6–1 Chelsea (1957–58 FA Youth Cup Final) – TheChels.info – The Chelsea Football Club Wiki |website=thechels.info |access-date=28 February 2019}}</ref> Block progressed to the Chelsea first team and made 40 appearances and scored six goals between 1957 and 1962.<ref name=\"stamfordbridge\">{{Cite web |url=http://www.stamford-bridge.com/player.php?id=46&surname=Block&firstname=Micky |title=Micky Block – Chelsea Player Profile – Stamford-Bridge.com The History of Chelsea FC |website=stamford-bridge.com |access-date=19 October 2015}}</ref>

column1: Block left Chelsea for [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] for £5
column2: 000 in January 1962.<ref name=\"Timeless\" /> While with Brentford
column3: he was the provider of [[Assist (soccer)|assists]] for many goals scored by the club's all-international frontline of [[Johnny Brooks]]
column4: [[Billy McAdams]] and [[John Dick (footballer
column5: born 1930)|John Dick]].<ref>{{Cite book |title=Brentford Football Club Official Matchday Magazine versus Barnsley 11/03/06 |year=2006 |page=54}}</ref> He later played for [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]
column6: <ref name=\"Watford\" /> before dropping into [[Non-League football|non-league football]] with [[Chelmsford City F.C.|Chelmsford City]] in 1967.<ref name=\"Watford\" />

| nationalteam1 = [[England national youth football team|England Youth]]

'''Michael Block''' (28 January 1940 – December 2019) was an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Midfielder#Winger|right winger]]. Block made nearly 200 [[English Football League|Football League]] appearances for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]
column2: [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] and [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] over a 10-year period.<ref name=\"Hugman\">{{Hugman|1744|accessdate=16 December 2016}}</ref>

Block began his career with in the youth team at [[Football League First Division|First Division]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and played in both legs of the [[FA Youth Cup Finals of the 1950s|1958 FA Youth Cup Final]].<ref name=\"Hugman\" /><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://thechels.info/wiki/Chelsea_5-1_Wolverhampton_Wanderers_(1957-58_FA_Youth_Cup_Final) |title=Chelsea 5–1 Wolverhampton Wanderers (1957–58 FA Youth Cup Final) – TheChels.info – The Chelsea Football Club Wiki |website=thechels.info |access-date=28 February 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://thechels.info/wiki/Wolverhampton_Wanderers_6-1_Chelsea_(1957-58_FA_Youth_Cup_Final) |title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 6–1 Chelsea (1957–58 FA Youth Cup Final) – TheChels.info – The Chelsea Football Club Wiki |website=thechels.info |access-date=28 February 2019}}</ref> Block progressed to the Chelsea first team and made 40 appearances and scored six goals between 1957 and 1962.<ref name=\"stamfordbridge\">{{Cite web |url=http://www.stamford-bridge.com/player.php?id=46&surname=Block&firstname=Micky |title=Micky Block – Chelsea Player Profile – Stamford-Bridge.com The History of Chelsea FC |website=stamford-bridge.com |access-date=19 October 2015}}</ref>

column1: Block left Chelsea for [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] for £5
column2: 000 in January 1962.<ref name=\"Timeless\" /> While with the Brentford
column3: he was the provider of [[Assist (soccer)|assists]] for many goals scored by the club's all-international frontline of [[Johnny Brooks]]
column4: [[Billy McAdams]] and [[John Dick (footballer
column5: born 1930)|John Dick]].<ref>{{Cite book |title=Brentford Football Club Official Matchday Magazine versus Barnsley 11/03/06 |year=2006 |page=54}}</ref> He later played for [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]
column6: <ref name=\"Watford\" /> before dropping into [[Non-League football|non-league football]] with [[Chelmsford City F.C.|Chelmsford City]] in 1967.<ref name=\"Watford\" />

column4:
[[File:Allessa-werkshafen-2010-ffm-mainkur-034.jpg|alt=A picture of the Mainkur port|thumb|AllessaChemie, Mainkur]]
[[File:Osthafen-oberhafen-II-ffm001.jpg|alt=A picture of the second basin|thumb|Becken II at Oberhafen]]
[[File:Westhafen_Frankfurt_W_DSCF3943.jpg|alt=A picture of the port at Westhafen|Westhafen port with residential areas to the side and the Westhafen Tower in the distance|thumb]]
[[File:Westhafen-2010-ffm-092.jpg|alt=A picture of the shop connected to the jetty|Jetty of the Kraftwerk West|thumb]]

[[Frankfurt am Main]] has multiple [[Inland port|inland ports]] which have been converted over time into new residential areas, owing to both their central location and the appeal of the view of the [[Main (river)]] from urban living spaces.

In the direction of flow, these [[Port|ports]] are:

* Port Mainkur (formerly Port Cassella) in the industrial area of [[Fechenheim]]. The port only has a small basin which is occasionally used to provide water to the companies located at the [[Cassella]] Industrial Park.
* [[Frankfurt Osthafen|Osthafen]] is the biggest port in Frankfurt and almost working at full capacity. It consists of the ''Oberhafen (Upper Harbour)'' and the ''Unterhafen'' ''(Lower Harbour)'' which are separated from each other by the [[Offenbach Barrage]]. Oberhafen consists of two basins, both of which flow directly into the Main, and is easily accessible from land via the [[Frankfurt City Link Line|Hafenbahn]] and the nearby A 661 [[Autobahn]]. A third, easterly basin was planned, but it was never built. The Unterhafen has the shape of a [[tuning fork]] and has a [[forebay (reservoir)]] which branches into two separate basins. A planned extension of the ''Nordbecken'' (north basin) was indeed excavated, but it was never connected to the basin. The pit filled up with [[groundwater]] and now forms the [[Schwedlersee]]. The [[Honsellbrücke]] crosses over the forebay and the [[Schmickbrücke]] crosses over the ''Südbecken'' (southern basin).
* The [[Mainkai]], located by the [[Altstadt (Frankfurt am Main)|Altstadt]], was the oldest port in the city. Today it serves as a waterfront. The extension of the Mainkai in the West towards the [[Main-Neckar-Brücke]] is called the [[Untermainkai]]. Until the mid-19th century a narrow [[tributary]] of the Main, called the ''Kleiner Main (Small Main),'' flowed underneath the quay's wall. The tributary was home to a small, off-shore island called ''Mainlust'', until the Kleiner Main was filled in during 1859. After the tributary had been filled in, the [[Nizza (Frankfurt)|Nizza]], an area of green space, developed. Tracks for the Verbindungsbahn still remain in the area, but now serve more of a tourist purpose for the [[Historic Railway, Frankfurt|Historic Railway]] than to transport goods. Companies such as ''Antwerpener Werft, Nizzawerft, Leonhardswert, Fahrtowerft,'' and ''Weseler Werft'' all make reference to the older usage of the port area as a shipyard (''Werft'' in German), as well as a historical loading crane located opposite the [[Städel Museum]]. By the [[Eiserner Steg]] there is still a landing stage for excursion ships; hotel ships also dock downstream to the [[Holbeinsteg]] during exhibition seasons.
* The '''Schaumainkai''', located on the [[Sachsenhausen (Frankfurt am Main)|Sachsenhausen]] side of the Main, has become synonymous with the [[Museumsufer]] — a series of museums all located along the Main. Whilst the museums reside by the high banks of the river, the Tiefkai, the lower part of the port, is a green area and one of the most attractive parts of the city. There also exist references here to the previous usage of the port as a shipyard, such as ''Schifferwerft, Dreikönigswerft, Deutschherrnwerft'', and ''Schlachthofwerft''.
* The [[Westhafen]] in the [[Gutleutviertel]] district was converted into an inner-city living quarter. The basin, now connected by two bridges, still remains accessible and serves as a [[yacht harbor]]. The neighbouring [[Heizkraftwerk West]] still continues to receive black coal by ship via its own landing stage.
* The The river port '''Gutleuthof''' downstream of the power plant is still in operation and has a rail connection to the port Hafenbahn.
* The loading dock at [[Griesheim Industry Park|Griesheim Industrial Park]] is still used, albeit it only rarely.
* The [[Höchster Hafen]] below the [[Höchster Altstadt]] was shut down in 1982. A gantry crane from the 1950s (extending to the height of the former power stations), as well as another crane from the 19th century at the mouth of the Niddamm, are reminders of the previous usage as a harbour.
* At the [[Höchst Industrial Park]], there are six dock shelters on the north bank for handling tankers. Between the [[Mittlere Werksbrück|mittlere Werksbrücke]] and the [[Leunabrücke]] is a quay wall several hundred meters long, where ships can also dock. The quay is mainly used to unload power plant coal for the park's combined heat and power plant. On the south side there is a 450-metre-long basin in which several ships can moor at the same time. It is mainly used for the delivery of rock salt for the [[Chloralkali process]] as well as container handling for the ''Rhine-Main Container Port''.

Cargo handling in the Frankfurt ports fluctuates depending on the economic situation, but is slightly declining overall. In 1997, a total of 8,439 ships were handled in all the Frankfurt ports, handling about 4.9 million tonnes of goods. By 2006, the figures had fallen to 5516 ships with approx. 3.5 million tonnes of goods handled.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://frankfurt.de/-/media/d438f2d4342749469924a1947109c1da.ashx|title=Statistisches Jahrbuch Frankfurt am Main 2007|last=|first=|date=|website=frankfurt.de|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=13 April 2020}}</ref> The decline in bulk goods such as coal, gravel and scrap metal plays a major role in this. In contrast, container handling plays has helped increase numbers. In 2015, 4.3 million tonnes of goods and 64,794 containers were handled in all Frankfurt ports<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://frankfurt.de/-/media/1f590915cd1a481c82b4411931085516.ashx|title=Statistisches Jahrbuch Frankfurt am Main 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=frankfurt.de|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=13 April 2020}}</ref>.

in 2008, 1917 ships with 2.38 million tons, including 42,652 container units, were handled in the city's ports<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924025958/http://www.hfm-frankfurt.de/images/stories/pdf/hfm_zahlen_daten_fakten_2009_100616.pdf|title=HFM Zahlen-Daten-Fakten 2009|last=|first=|date=|website=hfm-frankfurt.de|url-status=dead|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=13 April 2020}}</ref>. in 2011, 1745 ships with 2.0 million tons, including 28,495 containers<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924025954/http://www.hfm-frankfurt.de/images/stories/pdf/hfm_zahlen-daten-fakten_2011.pdf|title=Hafentour|last=|first=|date=|website=hfm-frankfurt.de|url-status=dead|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=13 April 2020}}</ref>. in 2015, 2113 ships were handled with a total of 2,569,287 tons, including 37,335 containers<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hfm-frankfurt.de/pdf/HFM_Zahlen-Daten-Fakten_2015_update.pdf|title=Hafentour|last=|first=|date=|website=hfm-frankfurt.de|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=13 April 2020}}</ref>.

About 1200 ships with about 1.9 million tons, including 32,000 containers, are handled in Höchst Industrial Park alone<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.industriepark-hoechst.com/de/stp/menue/der-industriepark-hoechst/daten-fakten/|title=DATEN & FAKTEN|last=|first=|date=|website=industriepark-hoechst.com|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=13 April 2020}}</ref>.

The documentary also shows what happens to children when they fail to arrive at their destination and are forced to go back to their countries of origin. Many of the other films that center around this topic feature similar stories

column12: and ''El Tren de la Muerte''. Most of these films have been acclaimed for bringing to light the many circumstances that migrants endure during their journey to the United States.

column8: and Mexico. Like many other children
column9: the kids in this documentary travel without an accompanying adult and their mode of transportation is \"El Tren de la Muerte.\" These stories focus on the emotional impact of the journey as well as the physical danger. The documentary also shows what happens to children when they fail to arrive at their destination and are forced to go back to their countries of origin. Many of the other films that center around this topic feature similar stories
column11: ''[[De Nadie]]''
column12: and ''El Tren de la Muerte''. Most of these films have been acclaimed for bringing to light the many circumstances that migrants endure during their journey to the United States.

column3: also depicts the process and obstacles of train migration. The book depicts the struggles and dangers of the journey north through the eyes of one migrant. It includes explicit details about migrants' encounters with street gangs
column4: corrupt officials
column5: hunger
column6: exhaustion
column7: discrimination
column8: poor weather

column1: El Salvadorian journalist Óscar Martínez's book [[The Beast (book)|The Beast]] also depicts the hardships faced by migrants on the journey to the United States.
Other forms of media have also discussed the topic of migration and the means by which migrants travel to the United States. The presses in Central America
column3: and the United States cover the topic with a particular focus on the grim and unfortunate aspects of the migration process.

'''Princess Maria Christina of Saxony''' (Maria Christina Anna Theresa Salomea Eulalia Francisca Xaveria; 12 February 1735 – 19 November 1782) was a Princess of Saxony and later [[Abbess of Remiremont]].

==Life==
She was the daughter of [[Augustus III of Poland]], [[Elector of Saxony]] (as Frederick Augustus II), [[King of Poland]] and [[Grand Duke of Lithuania]] (as Augustus II), and [[Maria Josepha of Austria]], first cousin of [[Empress Maria Theresa]]. 

Maria Christina was born at the [[Wilanów Palace]] in Poland. She came from a close family and her parents made sure they put emphasis on a good education. She was educated in [[Latin]], [[French language|French]], [[Polish language|Polish]], [[philosophy]], [[geography]], [[religion]], [[drawing]], [[music]] and [[dance]].

Her older sister [[Princess Maria Josepha of Saxony (1731–1767)|Maria Josepha]] married [[Louis, Dauphin of France (1729–1765)|Louis, Dauphin of France]] in 1747.<ref name=\Abbess\">{{cite web|url= http://www.guide2womenleaders.com/womeninpower/Womeninpower1770.htm |title= Women in Power 1770-1800 |accessdate= 2010-03-02|last= Christensen|first= Martin K.I|work= www.guide2womenleaders.com}}</ref>

column2: Maria Christina was sent to France to become a [[Coadjutor]]ice at the  [[Abbess of Remiremont|Abbey of Remiremont]] in [[Remiremont]]
column3: northern [[France]]. Her position was thanks to the personal intervention of [[Louis XV]] himself.<ref name=\"Abbess\"/>

column1: At the time of her arrival
column2: the abbey was under control of [[Princess Anne Charlotte of Lorraine]]
column4: Holy Roman Emperor|Holy Roman Emperor]] and aunt of the future [[Marie Antoinette]].<ref>Marie Antoinette would come to France in 1770 to wed the [[Louis XVI|Duke of Berry]]
column5: future Louis XVI</ref>

column2: she was known as ''Marie Christine de Saxe''.  In 1773
column3: at the death of Anne Charlotte
column4: Maria Christina was named Abbess
column5: a position she would keep until her death.

column1: Remiremont had seats and votes in the [[Reichstag (Holy Roman Empire)|Reichstag]] including all rights and obligations of an Imperial Princess (such as [[High
column4: [[legislation]]
column5: coinage and military service)
column6: and enjoyed immunity against [[Violence|temporal power]].

column1: She was a frequent visitor to [[Paris]] and was fond of the [[Theatre]] and the city's social life. She spent a great deal of money
column2: the payment of which was made by [[Stanisław Leszczyński]] ([[Duke of Lorraine]] until his death in 1766) and after that the king [[Louis XV]]. Her correspondence with her brother [[Prince Francis Xavier of Saxony|Francis Xavier
column3: Regent of Saxony]] was preserved at Trojes.

column1: She was created a Dame of the [[Order of the Starry Cross]].

Maria Christina bought the Château de Brumath in the town of [[Brumath]]<ref name=\"Brumath\">{{cite web|url= http://www.brumath.fr/mairie-brumath/decouvrir-ville-historique.html |title= ''Historique de Brumath'' |accessdate= 2010-03-05|last= |first=|work= www.brumath.fr}}</ref> in the [[Alsace]] region of France. Purchased in 1775
column2: <ref name=\"Brumath\"/> she chose the building for its location in the country and for its natural setting. She lived a lavish lifestyle at the [[château]] which far outdid her revenues.

column1: Dying at the château on 19 November 1782
column2: her nephew King [[Louis XVI]] was obliged to pay her debts in the amount of 136
column3: 876 livres for his dead aunt.<ref name=\"Brumath\"/>

column1: She was buried at the abbey in its ''église des Dames'' on the 15 December 1782. She was praised for her intelligence
column2: her conversation and for being a cultivated woman for her age. The château de Brumath was abandoned  and was pillaged in the [[French Revolution]].<ref name=\"Histoire\">{{cite web |url= http://www.prixeuropeendelitterature.eu/html/fichepays.asp?id=14 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110720171422/http://www.prixeuropeendelitterature.eu/html/fichepays.asp?id=14 |url-status= dead |archive-date= 2011-07-20 |title= ''Brève histoire de Brumath'' |accessdate= 2010-03-05 |work= www.prixeuropeendelitterature.eu }}</ref>

column4:
{{one source|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox Hollywood cartoon | name = Thru the Mirror | director = [[David Hand (director)|David Hand]] | story = [[William Cottrell (animator)|William Cottrell]]
[[Joe Grant]] | animator = Bob Wickersham | starring = [[Walt Disney]] | music = [[Frank Churchill]]
[[Leigh Harline]]
[[Paul Smith (film and television composer)|Paul J. Smith]] | producer = [[Walt Disney]] | studio = [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Walt Disney Productions]] | distributor = [[United Artists]] | released = May 30, 1936{{cite book |last1=Kaufman |first1=J.B. |last2=Gerstein |first2=David |title=Walt Disney's Mickey Mouse: The Ultimate History |date=2018 |publisher=Taschen |location=Cologne |isbn=978-3-8365-5284-4}} | color_process = [[Technicolor]] | runtime = 8 min (one reel) | language = [[English language|English]] }} '''''Thru the Mirror''''' is a [[Mickey Mouse]] [[cartoon]] [[short film]] produced by [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Walt Disney Productions]] and released by [[United Artists]] in [[1936 in film|1936]]. In this cartoon short, Mickey has a ''[[Through the Looking-Glass]]''-type dream that he travels through his mirror and enters a topsy-turvy world where everything is alive. While there, he engages in a [[Fred Astaire]] dance number with a pair of gloves and a pack of cards, until the cards chase him out of the bizarre world. The title is written as ''Thru the Mirror'' on the title card, but the alternative spelling '''''Through the Mirror''''' is used on the poster for the film. In addition, the short film is a parody of the book, ''Through the Looking Glass'', by Lewis Carroll. ==Synopsis== Mickey falls asleep after reading ''[[Through the Looking-Glass]]'' by [[Lewis Carroll]]. An astral projection of himself (presumably Mickey in his dream state) leaves his body and passes through his mirror into an alternate version of his house. His furniture and possessions have come to life and are complete with faces and personalities, but most of them remain motionless. He jumps on a rocking chair that throws him off in annoyance while a nearby coat rack watches in surprise, and lands on the footrest that behaves like a puppy while Mickey rides on it like a horse until it jumps into the rocking chair. While the chair tries to calm down the footrest, Mickey tries to comfort them, only to end up angering them instead. He bumps into an umbrella, who scolds him until it suddenly drops open and re-closes itself in embarrassment before returning to where it originally was. Mickey then comes across a nut cracker breaking open a walnut and offers it to him while it eats the shells. After eating the walnut, Mickey's lower body commences to wildly spin around, and it hits his face. While his lower body crazily spins, he suddenly becomes gigantic and then shrinks. The telephone suddenly rings and it throws its receiver down to Mickey, who uses it to climb up to the table. He attempts to answer the call, only to get responses from the phone itself and then proceeds to jump rope with the telephone, who uses its receiver and wire as a jump rope while the radio begins playing music. Mickey begins to dance his way through his house, tap dancing on a [[top hat]] (wearing a tiny one with a match for a cane) with some gloves (eventually he gets his butt kicked twice by the gloves), [[playing cards]] (some of them hit Mickey's butt during the dance), and eventually the [[Queen of Hearts (Alice's Adventures in Wonderland)|Queen of Hearts]] card (who resembles [[Greta Garbo]]). The [[joker (playing card)|joker]] on his bicycle notices and alerts the [[King of Hearts (Alice's Adventures in Wonderland)|King of Hearts]] who uses the joker's bike to get down there and pulls the queen aside before proceeding to fight for his lady in a sword duel with Mickey, who uses both a [[sewing needle]] and a [[Button (clothing)|button]] as a makeshift sword after the King of Hearts pushes him and gets his butt stabbed by the needle. Mickey defeats the king by pushing him into an inkwell, where a stamp takes him out and cleans him. Considering this as the last straw, the king then orders for the cards to be called out to get rid of Mickey for good and the radio acts as an alarm to summon the cards like police cars - \Calling all cards! Calling all cards!\" in which some come out from the king's throne and some come out from a drawer. Chaos ensues as Mickey runs from the cards. He picks up a fountain pen
column5: hides in a basket of yarn
column6: and uses the pen like a machine gun to fire ink at the cards while wearing a thimble-like a helmet. The pen eventually runs out of ink
column7: allowing the cards to pig-pile on Mickey
column8: who then escapes in a torn sock. After being spotted
column9: the cards give chase again and throw their pictures at him. Mickey then turns on an electric fan to blow the cards back while the telephone calls the police in panic as Mickey swings from a lamp rope and runs on a globe until he trips and falls into the globe's [[Bay of Bengal]] and is thrown out by a figure
column10: who appears to be a small version of Neptune
column11: by impaling Mickey's butt. He then grows back to his normal size and escapes back to the real world through the mirror where he reenters his body. Eventually
column12: he is awakened by his alarm clock and it has all been a dream and goes back to sleep after throwing his alarm clock into a drawer.

column3: in the 2002 video game ''[[Disney's Magical Mirror Starring Mickey Mouse]]''.

column2: ''Santa’s Workshop''. The music theme is based on Franz Schubert: Military March Op. 51 No. 1

column9: by impaling Mickey's butt. He then grows back to his normal size and escapes back to the real world through the mirror where he reenters his body. Eventually
column10: he is awakened by his alarm clock and it has all been a dream and goes back to sleep after throwing his alarm clock into a drawer.

column1: * 1981 – \"[[Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck Cartoon Collections]] Volume One\" (VHS)
* 1997 – ''[[The Ink and Paint Club (TV series)|The Ink and Paint Club]]''
* 2001 – \"[[Walt Disney Treasures: Wave One#Mickey Mouse in Living Color|Mickey Mouse in Living Color]]\" (DVD)
* 2004/2011 – Bonus on DVD release of ''[[Alice in Wonderland (1951 film)|Alice in Wonderland]]'' (DVD)
* 2009 – Walt Disney Animation Collection: ''[[Mickey and the Beanstalk]]'' (DVD)

column3: in the 2002 video game ''[[Disney's Magical Mirror Starring Mickey Mouse]]''.

column1: * Some elements from the cartoon like the cards and the opening were used in ''[[Epic Mickey]]''.
* The song during the magic gloves dance scene was used for the ''[[Walt Disney Mini Classics]]'' promos during their movie's end.
* The melody during Mickey’s marching with the cards in the middle of the film is a jazzed-up version of the music used in another 1932 cartoon classic
column2: ''Santa’s Workshop''. The music theme is based on Franz Schubert: Military March Op. 51 No. 1

column8: from the Time of King Edward III to Queen Victoria'' (London: George Willis
column11: accessed 11 August 2008</ref> and the name survives in 'Durward's'
column13: Essex|Bocking]] in Essex and in 'Durward's Hall'

column2: daughter and heiress of Sir [[William Coggeshall]] (1358–1426)
column3: High Sheriff of Essex.<ref>Pedigree of Dorward
column4: Heraldic Visitation of Essex
column6: p.104[https://archive.org/details/visitationsofess13metc/page/104]</ref> Arms of Dorward: ''Ermine
column7: on a chevron sable three crescents or ''<ref>As impaled by Fodringhay in the stained glass formerly at [[Beaupré Hall]]
column8: Norfolk</ref> His second wife was Isabella Baynard of [[Messing-cum-Inworth|Messing]]
column10: accessed 11 August 2008</ref> as named \"Isabella\" on his monument in St Mary's Church
column11: Bocking
column12: a daughter of Richard Baynard.<ref>Pedigree of Dorward
column15: p.104</ref> He had at least one son
column17: who in 1440 founded an [[almshouse]] to be called the Maison Dieu of the town of Bocking
column18: and later known as the Hospital of Bocking. Among its purposes was to pray for the soul of John Doreward
column20: in ''A History of the County of Essex: Volume 2'' (1907)

column1: Doreward was appointed [[High Sheriff of Essex]] and [[High Sheriff of Hertfordshire|Hertfordshire]] for 1399 and elected [[knight of the shire]] (MP) six times for [[Essex (UK Parliament constituency)|Essex]] (1395
column4: Jan 1404
column5: May 1413 and April 1414). He was elected Speaker of the House in 1399 and 1413.

column1: ''The Constitutional History of England in its Origin and Development''
column3: p. 18 ... In the case of Sir John Cheyne
column4: the Speaker elected in 1399
column5: the excuse of ill-health was accepted by the king as valid; the clergy had in fact objected to the nomination; Sir John Cheyne withdrew
column6: and John Doreward was chosen in his place.<ref>Stubbs p. 454</ref>

column2: writing about a hundred years after Doreward's first election as Speaker
column3: gives a more obscure version of events: {{quote|Than this feest with all honoure endyd
column4: upon the morn beyinge Tuysday
column5: the Parlyament was agayne begunne
column6: and upon Wedneysdaye Syr John Cheyney
column7: yt. before that tyme had occupyed as Speker of that Parlyament
column8: by his owne laboure
column9: for cause of such infyrmyties as he tha had
column11: and a Squyer named Wyllyam Durwarde was electe to that roume for hym.<ref name=manning/><ref>[[Robert Fabyan|Fabyan
column14: publ. as ''The New Chronicles of England and France'' (1515)</ref>}}

column1: The Parliament was almost identical in makeup to the previous parliament held under [[Richard II of England|Richard II]]
column2: where thanks to the political manoeuvring of [[John Bussy|Sir John Bussy]] many of Parliament's powers had been stripped from them and given instead to a committee. The summoning of this parliament showed good political judgement on the part of the ''de facto'' king
column3: [[Henry IV of England|Henry IV]]; in the words of Manning \"<nowiki>[Henry]</nowiki> could not have hoped to assemble a body of legislators less favourable to the captive monarch\"<ref name=manning/>

column1: The [[House of Commons of England|Commons]] voted a large subsidy to pay for the war against [[Scotland]] and the defence of [[Ireland]] and [[Calais]] in the hopes that their requests for additional powers would be granted. The commons also voted for the arrest of [[William le Scrope
column2: 1st Earl of Wiltshire|William Scrope]] and Henry Green

column1: Doreward was again made Speaker of the House of Commons for the parliament of 1413; this was the first of [[Henry V of England|Henry V]]
column2: and he was appointed again apparently after his predecessor had resigned from ill-health.<ref name=manning/> The parliament of 1413 granted Henry V a subsidy for four years; an unusually long period
column3: this is understood to be explained by the new king's popularity.

column1: Some historians have assumed that the John Doreward (or Dorewood) in the parliaments of 1399 and 1413 were father and son
column2: but they are evidently the same person; the Speaker of the House of Commons in both cases was a serjeant-at-law
column3: which was not an appointment held by either of Dorewood's sons.

column1: He was appointed a member of Henry IV's council from Nov 1399 to May 1406.
Doreward is commemorated by a [[monumental brass]] in St Mary's Church
column3: on the floor before the South Chapel. This gives the year of his death as 1420 and names his second wife as Isabella.<ref>[http://www.stmarys-bocking.co.uk/history.htm History] at stmarys-bocking.co.uk
column4: accessed 11 August 2008</ref> Inscribed in Latin: ''Exoretur mia(?) Dei p(ro) a(n)i(m)a(e) Joh(ann)is Doreward Armig(e)r(i) filii Will(ielm)i Doreward qui obi(i)t xii die mensis Novem(bris) An(no) D(omi)ni MCCCCXX et pro a(n)i(m)a Isabell(a)e ux(or)is eius quor(um) a(n)i(m)ab(us)z p(ro)pi(t)et(ur) Deus'' (\"Pray to God for the soul of John Doreward
column5: Esquire
column6: son of William Doreward who died on the 12 day of November AD 1420 and for the soul of Isabella his wife on the sould of whom may God look with favour\"
