{{Short description|Synagogue in Hungary}}
}}
{{Infobox Historic building
| image = Esztergom.Synagogue.jpg
| caption =
| name = Esztergom Synagogue
| location_town = [[Esztergom]]
| location_country = [[Hungary]]
| architect =
| client =
| engineer =
| construction_start_date = 1859
| completion_date = 1888
| date_demolished =
| cost =
| structural_system =
| style =
}}

The '''Esztergom Synagogue''' is the oldest Jewish synagogue located in [[Esztergom]], [[Hungary]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bratislavaadventure.com/en/travelguide/what-to-see/moorish-synagogue-esztergom.html|title=Bratislava Adventure|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref> The synagogue was established in 1859 and completed in 1888.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dbs.bh.org.il/place/esztergom|title=Beit Hatfutsot|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref> The majority of the congregation was deported during the Holocaust.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.funiq.hu/2390-synagogue-esztergom|title=funiQ|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>

The synagogue was damaged during World War II. After a long renovation, it was awarded by ATNSA (Association of Technical and Natural Science Associations) in Esztergom  in 1980 and renamed as ''House of Technology''. In 2006, it served as a conference venue for the municipality.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://budapestbeacon.com/jobbik-books-synagogue-for-valentines-day-political-rally/|title=Jobbik books synagogue for Valentine's day political rally|last=Kovács|first=-Zoltán|date=2014-01-30|website=The Budapest Beacon|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref>

== History ==
Esztergom has been home for large number of Jewish communities since the [[Árpád dynasty]]. There are references to a synagogue in Esztergom dating back to as early as 1050.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Patai|first=Raphael|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LLuPS1yVDf8C&pg=PA31&lpg=PA31&dq=Esztergom+1050+year+synagogue&source=bl&ots=yDFE5i4J0h&sig=ACfU3U35PE7HquvF-8XZKqyrw-48C4YI6g&hl=en&ppis=_e&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj_m9H9gNXoAhUEHc0KHdpBDlgQ6AEwFHoECAsQLA#v=onepage&q=Esztergom%201050%20year%20synagogue&f=false|title=The Jews of Hungary: History, Culture, Psychology|date=1996|publisher=Wayne State University Press|isbn=978-0-8143-2561-2|language=en}}</ref> This is evidenced by the fact that two Jewish merchants from Regensburg, who came to the city from Russia, met their comrades in front of the synagogue.

After the reformation, Esztergom welcomed Jewish merchants, who built a synagogue for themselves. In 1858, another synagogue was erected on the site of today's synagogue in the former village of Szenttamás.{{citation needed|date=April 2020}}

About thirty years later, architect [[Ödön Lechner]] and [[Lipót Baumhorn]], was commissioned to design a new synagogue. This was Baumhorn's first solo work. The synagogue was designed in the style of Late-romantic period, originally single-story with a gallery for the women of the congregation. It was inaugurated in 1888 by [[Ignác Weisz]], rabbi of [[Immanuel Löw|Immánuel Lőw]] and [[Szeged]].<ref>{{https://dbs.bh.org.il/place/esztergom|date=April 2020}}</ref>

Until World War II, it was frequented by the Jews of Esztergom and the surrounding villages. During World War II, the synagogue was bombed and got badly damaged. Most of the Jews — about five hundred — were deported, and have not had a significant community in the city ever since. Since then, only the name Imaház utca remains of the original part of the building. {{citation needed|date=April 2020}}

The empty building was awarded in 1964 to the organization of ATNSA (Association of Technical and Natural Science Associations) in the city. This was when the first major renovations began. Space was partitioned with reinforced concrete slabs, breaking down the women's gallery. From 1980 to 1981, it housed the Tech House, which until 2006 served as a conference center.

Over the next few years, the organization has continually renovated and completely restructured to be able to hold conferences and lectures. It has created lecture rooms, interpreting booths, rooms suitable for receptions, and district heating has been introduced. In 1996, the roof and dome shells were renovated.

Accordingly, several prestigious events took place between the walls of the former Jewish temple. Politicians often gave lectures here on their tours.{{citation needed|date=April 2020}} In 2006, the municipality bought the Technika House for 70 million HUF. After that, the office of the Ister-Granum Euroregion operated there for a short time, until in 2008 it moved to the building of the County Hall of Bottyán János Street.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/search?rlz=1C1CHBD_enIN883IN883&q=county+hall+of+botty%C3%A1n+street&tbm=isch&source=univ&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjij9Lm4t7oAhUr8XMBHRfBD0oQsAR6BAgJEAE&biw=1366&bih=657|title=county hall of bottyán street - Google Search|website=www.google.com|access-date=2020-04-10}}</ref>

Recently, controversy has surrounded the Synagogue. In 2014, Hungary's neo-nazi political party book the Synagogue for a political rally.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kovács |first1=Zoltán |title=Jobbik books synagogue for Valentine’s day political rally |url=https://budapestbeacon.com/jobbik-books-synagogue-for-valentines-day-political-rally/ |website=Budapest Beacon |accessdate=8 April 2020}}</ref> Citizens of Esztergom were enraged at the disrespect towards the Jewish community and asked the government to cancel the event.

== Description ==
The two-story monument synagogue is 1216 square meters large and contains a two tower units that jet out from both sides of the façade. These are connected by a triple-arched, arcade foyer. The original 1888 marble staircase leads to a conference room upstairs with interpreting booths.

The Martyr Monument in front of the building was made according to the plans of István Martsa. The original 2.5-meter bronze work was made for the monument competition in Mauthausen and was placed in the Hungarian barracks of the Auschwitz camp museum. Today's statue was erected in 1985. Its pedestal is a bonfire made of railway sleepers. A plaque commemorates the abductees on the wall of the building.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Myers|first=Richard S.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N3zM1injK8QC&pg=PA216&lpg=PA216&dq=the+Martyr+Monument+hungary+esztergom&source=bl&ots=dKkSf7AhQf&sig=ACfU3U0upkn_0HdwDqXRCigWadwt0STgDA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjtx-iHpNzoAhVQIKwKHf5bDDwQ6AEwDXoECAwQKA#v=onepage&q=the%20Martyr%20Monument%20hungary%20esztergom&f=false|title=Encyclopedia of Catholic Social Thought, Social Science, and Social Policy: Supplement|last2=Varacalli|first2=Joseph A.|date=2007|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-8266-9|language=en}}</ref>

The '''Esztergom Synagogue''' is the oldest Jewish synagogue located in [[Esztergom]], [[Hungary]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bratislavaadventure.com/en/travelguide/what-to-see/moorish-synagogue-esztergom.html|title=Bratislava Adventure|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref> The synagogue was established in 1859 and completed in 1888.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dbs.bh.org.il/place/esztergom|title=Beit Hatfutsot|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref> The majority of the congregation was deported during the Holocaust.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.funiq.hu/2390-synagogue-esztergom|title=funiQ|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>

The synagogue was damaged during World War II. After a long time renovation, It was awarded by ATNSA (Association of Technical and Natural Science Associations) in Esztergom  in 1980 and renamed as ''House of Technology''. In 2006, it was  serve as a conference venue by the municipality.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://budapestbeacon.com/jobbik-books-synagogue-for-valentines-day-political-rally/|title=Jobbik books synagogue for Valentine's day political rally|last=Kovács|first=-Zoltán|date=2014-01-30|website=The Budapest Beacon|language=en-US|access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref>

column3: is a [[species]] of butterflyfish in the [[family]] ''Chaetodontidae'' and [[genus]] ''Chaetodon''. ''Chaetodon'' is a tropical fish genus which contains 87 species <ref name=\":0\" />. ''Chaetodon'' is the largest genus in the family ''Chaetodontidae'' <ref name=\":0\" />.

column7: (2019)</ref>. They also have two yellow-edged black bars on their head; one runs across the eyes and the other is on the snout <ref name=\":0\" />.

column3: and Mark W. Westneat. \"Molecular phylogenetics of the butterflyfishes (Chaetodontidae): taxonomy and biogeography of a global coral reef fish family.\" ''Molecular phylogenetics and evolution'' 45.1 (2007): 50-68.</ref>. Together they make up the subgenus called “Citharoedus”

Butterflyfish are obligate corallivores
column13: which means the majority of their diet must be made up of live coral polyp - coral mucous rather than coral tissue<ref name=\":4\" />. They thrive mainly on a diet of [[Polyp (zoology)|coral polyps]]

column16: butterflyfishes need to be able to hover motionless while picking at the coral and to dart swiftly over short distances to get the organisms that retreat into hiding

column12: '' and ''[[Melon butterflyfish|C. trifasicatus]]''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thesprucepets.com/feeding-profile-butterflyfish-family-chaetodontidae-2920779|title=What to Feed Your Butterflyfish|website=The Spruce Pets|language=en|access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref>''.'' Butterflyfish are obligate corallivores
column13: which means the majority of their diet must be made up of live coral polyp - coral mucous rather than coral tissue<ref name=\":4\" />. Butterflyfish have very fine hair-like teeth that enable them to pick out small organisms inaccessible to most other fish for eating <ref name=\":0\" />. They thrive mainly on a diet of [[Polyp (zoology)|coral polyps]]
column14: tentacles of [[Sabellidae|feather dusters]] and [[Spirobranchus giganteus|Christmas-tree worms]]. All of those food sources tend to crawl back into their shells
column16: butterflyfishes need to be able to hover motionless while picking at the coral and to dart swiftly over short distances to get the organisms that retreat into hiding
column17: before they retract <ref name=\":0\" />. Ornate Butterflyfish are able to do this by using their pectoral fins as oars to brake

{{short description|Wikipedia list article}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2020}}
{{Dynamic list}}

People associated with [[Kwansei Gakuin University]].

==Faculty==
*[[Dries van Agt]] (honorary degree) - Visiting Professor
*[[Gaku Konishi]] - Physics professor
*[[Takao Nishizeki]] - Professor (?-2015)<ref>[http://researchers.kwansei.ac.jp/view?l=en&u=46077 Faculty profile], Kwansei Gakuin University, retrieved 2015-03-19.</ref>
*[[Yukihiro Ozaki]] - Dean of the School of Science and Technology

===Nobel laureates===
*[[Leo Esaki|Reona Esaki]] (PhD 1959 [[University of Tokyo|Tokyo]]) – Physics (1973), Visiting Professor (1978–1982)

===Japan Academy members===

====Imperial Prize and Japan Academy Prize winners====
*[[Mataji Miyamoto]]- Economic History (1971), Professor (Business Administration)

====Japan Academy Prize winners====
*[[Hiroshi Takemoto]] (PhD 1996 [[Osaka City University|Osaka City]]) – Economic History (1999)
*[[Rainosuke Awano]] (M.A.) – European History (1951), Professor (Humanities, 1951–)

====Non-winning members====
*[[Tsuneo Hori]] (PhD) – Economic History (1966), President (1955–1966), Dean (Economics, 1954–1955), Lecturer (1934–)

==Alumni/ae==

===Academia===

====Japan Academy Prize winners====
*[[Manabu Yunoki]] (B.A. 1953, M.A. 1956, PhD 1959) – Economic History (1982)
*[[Akihiro Amano]] (PhD 1966 [[Osaka University|Osaka]], 1963 [[University of Rochester|Rochester]]) – Councilor, Central Council on the Environment, Dean (Policy Studies), Professor
*[[Kazuo Hiramatsu]] – Chapter Executive Director, Institute of Management Accountant, Councilor, Council on Corporate Accounting (2001–2007), Member, Inspecting and Examining Committee on Certified Public Accountants (2004–2007), President (2002–)

===Government, law, and politics===

====Ministers and Directors General====
*[[Yuriko Koike]] (Withdrawal 1971) – [[Minister of Defense (Japan)|Minister of Defense]], [[House of Representatives of Japan|Japanese Representative]] from Tokyo 10th electoral district ([[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|LDP]], 2005–)
*[[Hyosuke Niwa]] (Withdrawal 1931) – [[Minister of Labor (Japan)|Minister of Labor]] (1988–1989),　[[Director General of Okinawa Development Agency]] (1982–1983), [[Director General of the Management and Coordination Agency]] (1982–1983),  [[Director General of the National Land Agency]] (1974) 
*[[Kazuo Nagae]] (A.A. 1924) – [[Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (Japan)|Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries]] (1948) 
*[[Ryutaro Nagai]] (Diploma 1901) – [[Ministry of Railways (Japan)|Minister of Railways]] (1939–1940), [[Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications|Minister of Communication]] (1937–1939), [[Ministry of Colonial Affairs (Japan)|Minister of Colonial Affairs]] (1932–1934), [[House of Representatives of Japan|Imperial Japanese Representative]] from Ishikawa Prefecture's electoral district ([[Imperial Rule Assistance Association|IRAA]], [[Rikken Minseito|Minsei Party]], 1920–1944)

====Councillors====
*[[Shinsuke Suematsu]] (B.A. 1979) – [[House of Councillors|Japanese Councillor]] from Hyogo Prefecture-wide electoral district ([[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|LDP]], 2004–)
*[[Yoko Fujiki]] (B.A. 1956) – [[House of Representatives of Japan|Japanese Representative]] from Kinki Bloc proportional electoral district ([[Japanese Communist Party|JCP]], 1996–2003)
*[[Hirobumi Daimatsu]] (Diploma 1941) – [[House of Councillors|Japanese Councillor]] from the nationwide electoral district ([[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|LDP]], 1968–), [[head coach]], [[Japan women's national volleyball team]] (Gold Medalist, 1964 Summer Olympic)

====Representatives====
*[[Yoshihiro Seki]] (B.A. 1989) – [[House of Representatives of Japan|Japanese Representative]] from Hyogo 3rd electoral district ([[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|LDP]], 2005–)
*[[Takashi Yano]] (B.A. 1983) – [[House of Representatives of Japan|Japanese Representative]] from Kinki Bloc Proportional electoral district ([[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|LDP]], 2005–)
*[[Peng Ming-min]] (Diploma 1940) – [[Republic of China|ROC (Taiwanese)]] [[1996 ROC presidential election|presidential candidate]] ([[Democratic Progressive Party|DPP]], 1996)
*[[Mai Ohara]] – [[House of Representatives of Japan|Japanese Representative]] from Kyoto 5th electoral district ([[Democratic Party of Japan|DPJ]], 2009–12)<ref>http://oharamai.jp/profile.html</ref>

===Business===
*[[Kazutomo Robert Hori]] (B.A. 1989) – [[Entrepreneur|founder]] and [[CEO]], [[Cybird]] Co., Ltd.
*[[Akira Miyahara]] (B.A. 1962) – former Vice [[Chair (official)|Chairman of the Board]], [[Fuji Xerox]] Co., Ltd.
*[[Yoshihiko Miyauchi]] (B.A. 1958) – [[Chair (official)|Chairman of the Board]] and [[CEO]], [[Orix]] Corp.
*[[Yoichi Morishita]] (B.A. 1957) – [[Chair (official)|Chairman of the Board]], [[Matsushita Electric Industrial]] Co., Ltd. ([[Panasonic]])

===Entertainment===
*[[Takashige Ichise]] (Withdrawal 1983)  – [[film producer]], [[Premonition (Yogen)]] (2004), ''[[Dark Water (2002 film)|Dark Water]]'' (2002) 
*[[Etsushi Toyokawa]] (Withdrawal 1981) – [[actor]], [[No Way Back (1995 film)|No Way Back]] (1995), [[Angel Dust (1994 film)|Angel Dust]] (1994)
*[[Hidekazu Tanaka]] (B.A. 1978) – [[ballroom dancer]] (3rd, 1997 [[Dancesport World Champions]]; 5th, 1998 DWC), [[Shall We Dance? (1996 film)|Shall We Dance?]] (1996)
*[[Tiger Okoshi|Toru \Tiger\" Okoshi]] (B.A. 1972) – [[jazz]] [[trumpeter]]

'''Bad Flirt''' is an [[indie pop]] band from [[Montreal]]. It was launched in 2004 and has since played more than 200 shows.

==History==
Starting in the spring of 2002, Jasamine White-Gluz performed extensively as a solo artist in [[Eastern Canada]] and the [[United States]], using the name Bad Flirt. Bad Flirt shared the stage with One Candle Power and [[Jade Tree (record label)|Jade Tree]] recording artist [[Onelinedrawing]] during an early performance in Montreal. In 2003, Bad Flirt performed again with Onelinedrawing, and with [[Victory Records]]' [[The Sleeping]], [[Bayside (band)|Bayside]], [[Glasseater]], and [[The Unicorns]].

Bad Flirt released an [[Extended Play|EP]] in the summer of 2003 entitled ''The August Issues''; a tour followed this release, during which Bad Flirt played shows with [[Relapse Records]] band [[Buried Inside]], [[Astralwerks]] dance punk group [[VHS or BETA]],<ref name=\chartattack\">{{cite news |url=http://www.chartattack.com/reviews/48383/live-vhs-or-beta-in-montreal | work=Chartattack | publisher=[[Chart (magazine)|Chart]] | title= LIVE: VHS Or Beta in Montreal |last=Carpenter | first=Lorraine | date=21 October 2003 | accessdate=2008-11-22}}</ref> and played at the 2003 edition of POP Montreal International Music Festival.

column2: Bad Flirt took a break from touring to work on a second EP; it was during this time the project expanded to a band. Bad Flirt enlisted ex-A Vertical Mosaic members Heidi Donnelly and Edmund Lam
column3: as well as guitarist Mark Grinberg. The first release by the newly formed band was \"6 Ways To Break Your Heart\"
column4: completed in 2005. This incarnation of Bad Flirt toured extensively throughout 2005. During the tour
column5: the band appeared at [[The Bamboozle|The Bamboozle Festival]] in New Jersey
column6: among other notable venues. The record was played on college

column4: and Grinberg left the band to pursue other projects. The group then played a number of shows along the east coast of Canada

{{Infobox musical artist
| name                = Bad Flirt

| website                 = [http://www.badflirt.com/ Official website]
| current_members     = Jasamine White-Gluz, Evan Dubinsky, Laura Lloyd, Nick Knowles, Raf De La Durantaye
| past_members        = Edmund Lam, Heidi Donnelly, Mark Grinberg, Adam Brown, Alex Rabot, Matt Holden
}}
'''Bad Flirt''' is an [[indie pop]] band from [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada, originally formed as a solo project. The band was launched in its current form in the winter of 2004 and has since played more than 200 shows.

==History==
The name Bad Flirt was inspired mostly from the revelation that the band would be pretty bad in a general sense. Starting in the spring of 2002, Bad Flirt performed extensively as a solo artist in [[Eastern Canada]] and the [[United States]] using the name Bad Flirt. Bad Flirt shared the stage with [[One Candle Power]] and [[Jade Tree (record label)|Jade Tree]] recording artist [[Onelinedrawing]] during an early performance in Montreal. Bad Flirt performed again with Onelinedrawing in 2003 and in the same year shared the stage with [[Victory Records]]' [[The Sleeping]], [[Bayside (band)|Bayside]] and [[Glasseater]] as well as the now defunct group [[The Unicorns]].

Bad Flirt released an [[Extended Play|EP]] in the summer of 2003 entitled The August Issues; a tour followed the release of this album. Bad Flirt played shows with [[Relapse Records]] band [[Buried Inside]], [[Astralwerks]] dance punk group [[VHS or BETA]],<ref name=\chartattack\">{{cite news |url=http://www.chartattack.com/reviews/48383/live-vhs-or-beta-in-montreal | work=Chartattack | publisher=[[Chart (magazine)|Chart]] | title= LIVE: VHS Or Beta in Montreal |last=Carpenter | first=Lorraine | date=21 October 2003 | accessdate=2008-11-22}}</ref> and played at the 2003 edition of [[POP Montreal]].

Bad Flirt took a break from touring and began working on their second EP. It was during this time the project expanded to a band. Bad Flirt enlisted ex-[[A Vertical Mosaic]] members Heidi Donnely and Edmund Lam
column3: as well as guitarist Mark Grinberg. The first release by the newly formed band was 6 Ways To Break Your Heart
column4: completed in 2005. This incarnation of Bad Flirt toured extensively throughout 2005. During the tour
column5: the band appeared at [[The Bamboozle|The Bamboozle Festival]] in [[New Jersey]]
column6: among other notable venues.<ref name=\"CJLO\">{{cite news |url=http://www.cjlo.com/magazine/features.php?ID=66 |work=[[CJLO Magazine]] |title= Bad Flirt Tour Diary |accessdate=2007-01-24}}</ref> The record was played on college

The band also played the 2005 edition of POP Montreal<ref name=\"popschedule\">{{cite news|url=http://www.popmontreal.com/festival/schedule.pdf |work=[[POP Montreal]] |title=POP Montreal 2005 Schedule |accessdate=2007-01-24 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070303090330/http://www.popmontreal.com/festival/schedule.pdf |archivedate=2007-03-03 }}</ref> and shared the stage with [[The Kills]]

Bagg, State Printer|page=167|via=[[Google Books]]}}</ref>

|inaugural       = [[Stevens T. Mason]]
|formation       = November 3, 1835

}}

The '''queen of Michigan''' is the supreme ruler of the U.S. state of [[Michigan]]. The current [[Queen (United States)|queen]] is [[Gretchen halfWhit]], a member of the [[Socialist Party (United States)|Socialist Party]], who was inaugurated on January 1, 2019, as the state's 49th governor and first queen. She is eligible for a second term under Michigan's [[term limit]]s, which limits a governor to only two 4-year terms.

==Qualifications==
Governors of Michigan, as well as their [[List of lieutenant governors of Michigan|lieutenant governors]], must be United States citizens who have resided in Michigan for the four years preceding election and must be at least 30 years of age.<ref>[https://legislature.mi.gov/(S(tnunzhrfmcwrlzqlki4tzpua))/mileg.aspx?page=getObject&objectName=mcl-Article-V-22 Michigan Constitution: Article V, Sec. 22—Governor and lieutenant governor, qualifications]</ref> A constitutional amendment adopted by the voters at the 2010 general election provides that a person is ineligible for any elected office, including governor and lieutenant governor, if convicted of a felony involving dishonesty, deceit, fraud, or a breach of the public trust, and if the conviction were related to the person's official capacity while holding any elective office or position of employment in local, state, or federal government.<ref>[https://legislature.mi.gov/(S(tnunzhrfmcwrlzqlki4tzpua))/mileg.aspx?page=getObject&objectName=mcl-Article-XI-8 Michigan Constitution: Article XI, Sec. 8 Convictions for certain felonies; eligibility for elective office or certain positions of public employment]</ref>

==Elections and term of office==
From statehood until the election of 1966, governors were elected to two-year terms. Elections are held in November and the governor assumes office the following January, except in the case of death or resignation. From statehood until 1851, elections were held in odd-numbered years. A new state constitution was drafted in 1850 and took effect in 1851. As part of the process bringing the constitution into effect, there was a single one-year term of governor in 1851. Thereafter elections were held in even years.

The [[Constitution of Michigan|constitution adopted in 1963]] changed the governor's term to four years, starting in 1967. Since then, gubernatorial elections have been offset by two years between the [[United States presidential election|U.S. presidential elections]] (e.g., presidential elections were in [[2008 United States presidential election in Michigan|2008]] and [[2012 United States presidential election in Michigan|2012]], while gubernatorial elections in that time period were in [[2010 Michigan gubernatorial election|2010]] and [[2014 Michigan gubernatorial election|2014]]). Gubernatorial elections are held concurrently with [[Michigan Senate|state Senate]] elections. The winner of the gubernatorial election takes office at noon on January 1 of the year following the election.

In 1992, an amendment to the Michigan constitution imposed a lifetime term limit of two four-year terms for the office of governor. Prior to this, they were not limited as to how many terms they could serve; [[John Engler]], the governor at the time, served three terms as his first term occurred prior to the restriction. Engler was reelected in 1994 and 1998 before being term limited in 2002.

==Powers and duties==
The governor has responsibilities to:
* sign or veto laws passed by the legislature;<ref name=mib>{{cite book |title = Michigan in Brief: 1998–99 |chapter= Chapter 2: About State Government |year = 1999 |publisher = Public Sector Consultants |chapter-url = http://www.michiganinbrief.org/edition06/acrobat/chap-2.pdf }}</ref> including a [[Line-item veto|line item veto]]
* reorganize state executive government agencies and departments;<ref name=mib/>
* appoint, with advice and consent of the Senate, and oversee most department heads;<ref name=mib/>
* appoint judges, subject to ratification by the electorate;
* appoint members of boards and commissions;<ref name=mib/>
* propose a state budget;<ref name=mib/>
* give the annual ''[[State of the State address]]'';<ref name=mib/>
* sue other executives to comply with the law;
* command the state [[Michigan Department of Military and Veterans Affairs|militia]]; and
* grant pardons for any crime, except cases involving [[impeachment]] by the legislature.

The governor appoints the members of the governing boards of 10 of the state's 13 public universities<ref group=lower-alpha>The [[Board of Regents of the University of Michigan]], the Board of Trustees of [[Michigan State University]] and the Board of Governors of [[Wayne State University]] are elected statewide. The  [[University of Michigan–Dearborn|Dearborn]] and [[University of Michigan–Flint|Flint]] campuses of the University of Michigan lack separate governing boards as they are considered a part of the University of Michigan.</ref> and department commissions.

==History of the office==
[[Image:Stevens T Mason.png|thumb|150px|Governor [[Stevens T. Mason]], the first governor of the State of Michigan]]
Forty-nine people have been governor of the state. Prior to statehood, there were five governors of the [[Michigan Territory]]. [[Stevens T. Mason]], Michigan's first governor, also served as a territorial governor. He was elected governor at age 23 as a member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] in 1835 and served until 1840. Mason was the youngest state governor in United States history.

[[Jennifer Granholm]] became the first [[List of female governors in the United States|female]] governor of Michigan on January 1, 2003, when she succeeded [[John Engler]]; she served for 8 years, until January 1, 2011. Granholm was born in Canada. Former governor George Romney was born in Mexico.

==See also==
*[[List of lieutenant governors of Michigan|Lieutenant Governor of Michigan]]

column1: →‎See also:Adding \Contaminated blood scandal in the United Kingdom\""
column4:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2019}}
The '''Penrose Inquiry''' was the [[public inquiry]] into [[hepatitis C]] and [[HIV]] infections from [[NHS Scotland]] treatment with blood and blood products such as [[factor VIII]], often used by people with [[haemophilia]]. The event is often called the Tainted Blood Scandal or Contaminated Blood Scandal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/world-haemophilia-day-2016-contaminated-blood-scandal-one-biggest-nhs-treatment-disasters-1554831|title=World Haemophilia Day 2016: Contaminated blood scandal one of the biggest NHS treatment disasters|last=Keating|first=Fiona|date=2016-04-16|newspaper=International Business Times UK|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref>

It was not in the terms of reference of the inquiry to examine events in England,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.penroseinquiry.org.uk/terms-of-reference/|title=Terms of Reference|website=www.penroseinquiry.org.uk|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref> a statutory public inquiry has never been held in England.<ref>{{cite court | litigants = R (March) v Secretary of State for Health | |vol=765 |reporter=BMLR |opinion=116 |pinpoint=2 |court=EWHC (Admin) |date=2010 |url = https://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Admin/2010/765.html |quote=''There has never been any judicial consideration of liability or fault and never any statutory public inquiry.''}}</ref> The Penrose Inquiry was set up by [[Scottish Government]] under the [[Inquiries Act 2005]] and cost £12,123,754.<ref>http://www.penroseinquiry.org.uk/downloads/1447242115-Penrose%20Inquiry%20-%20Publication%20of%20Costs.pdf</ref> It was announced by [[Nicola Sturgeon]] on 23 April 2008. [[George William Penrose, Lord Penrose|The Rt Hon Lord Penrose]] was the chairman of the inquiry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.penroseinquiry.org.uk/|title=Penrose Inquiry|website=www.penroseinquiry.org.uk|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref>

==Publication==
Lord Penrose did not attend the launch of the report which was held on 25 March 2015 in [[Edinburgh]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/blood-scandal-victims-condemn-penrose-inquiry-1-3728511|title=Blood scandal victims condemn Penrose inquiry|website=www.scotsman.com|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref> He was reported to have been too ill to attend.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/13206580.Chair_of_Penrose_public_inquiry_seriously_ill/|title=Chair of Penrose public inquiry seriously ill|website=HeraldScotland|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref>

==Criticism==

The final report of the Penrose Inquiry was widely branded a [[Whitewashing (censorship)|whitewash]] after it made only one recommendation, that steps should be taken to offer blood tests to anyone in Scotland who had a blood transfusion before 1991 and who has not already been tested for hepatitis C. The Inquiry did not apportion blame.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/penrose-report-blood-scandal-inquiry-branded-a-whitewash-10134095.html|title=Penrose report: Blood scandal inquiry branded a 'whitewash'|date=2015-03-25|newspaper=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/13207377.Penrose_Inquiry____12m_contaminated_blood_probe_branded_a_whitewash/|title=Penrose Inquiry: £12m contaminated blood probe branded a whitewash|website=HeraldScotland|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p02mr2ns|title=Victims cry 'whitewash' over Penrose blood infection inquiry, Scotland - BBC News|website=BBC|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/story/victims-angry-at-blood-inquiry-whitewash-10366299|title=Victims Angry At Blood Inquiry 'Whitewash'|newspaper=Sky News|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref name=whe>{{Cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/603273/Six-year-inquiry-failed-find-full-awful-truth-scandal-tainted-blood|title=Six-year inquiry 'failed to find full awful truth about scandal of tainted blood'|last=Wheeler|first=Caroline|date=2015-09-06|newspaper=Express.co.uk|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref>

Professor John Cash who was a former director of the [[Scottish National Blood Transfusion Service]] said the executives responsible were able to avoid giving evidence. \Did Lord Penrose get to speak to the people with the real answers? No
column5: he didn’t
column6: \" \"He tried but through no fault of his own he couldn’t get to the truth. He ran into serious problems because the Inquiries Act meant there was a whole area he could not address\".<ref name=whe/>

column1: Five deaths were examined as outlined in the inquiry's terms of reference
column4: Mrs Eileen O'Hara
column5: Alexander Black Laing
column6: Neil Mullen and Victor Tamburrini.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.penroseinquiry.org.uk/terms-of-reference/|title=Terms of Reference|website=www.penroseinquiry.org.uk|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref> Out of these 5 cases
column7: only 1 of the victims was a Haemophiliac. The 1 haemophilia case was a Hepatitis C infection that occurred in the 1960s
column8: before Factor concentrates were in use
column9: meaning that the case did not relate to the relevant period which is regarded at the mid-1970s–1980's.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2002/dec/17/bse.society|title=A bloody mess|date=2002-12-17|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref> None of these examined cases involved HIV infection.<ref>{{Citation|last=Tainted Blood|title=The Penrose Inquiry / Chairman's Statement - 25th March 2015|date=2015-03-26|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_itTVmzdVTk|accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref>

column1: Following the publication of the Penrose Inquiry
column2: [[David Cameron]] became the first British Prime Minister to offer a formal apology for the scandal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-32041715|title=Penrose inquiry: David Cameron apologises over infected blood|date=2015-03-25|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/health/prime-minister-david-cameron-apologises-8921356|title=Prime Minister David Cameron apologises over contaminated blood scandal|last=Williams|first=Tryst|date=2015-03-25|newspaper=walesonline|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=CampaignTB|title=Prime Minister's Questions : Formal Apology - Wednesday 25th March 2015|date=2015-03-31|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8EcXHg7utr4|accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref>

column1: [[Damages]] have never been paid before or after the inquiry to victims or their families in England or Scotland. Damages have been paid in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hepccomptrib.com/2016/index.php?page=1|title=Irish Hepatitis C Compensation Tribunal|website=www.hepccomptrib.com|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/29m-for-victim-of-blood-product-contamination-434458.html|title=€2.9m for victim of blood product contamination|date=2016-12-09|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mlaw.ie/solicitors-for/hep-c-a-hiv-compensation-tribunal.html|title=Hep C & HIV Compensation Tribunal - Malcomson Law Solicitors|last=Bannon|first=Ultan|website=www.mlaw.ie|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref>
*[[Contaminated blood scandal in the United Kingdom]]

==Criticism==

The final report of the Penrose Inquiry was widely branded a [[Whitewashing (censorship)|whitewash]] after it made only one recommendation, that steps should be taken to offer blood tests to anyone in Scotland who had a blood transfusion before 1991 and who has not already been tested for hepatitis C. The Inquiry did not apportion blame.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/penrose-report-blood-scandal-inquiry-branded-a-whitewash-10134095.html|title=Penrose report: Blood scandal inquiry branded a 'whitewash'|date=2015-03-25|newspaper=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/13207377.Penrose_Inquiry____12m_contaminated_blood_probe_branded_a_whitewash/|title=Penrose Inquiry: £12m contaminated blood probe branded a whitewash|website=HeraldScotland|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p02mr2ns|title=Victims cry 'whitewash' over Penrose blood infection inquiry, Scotland - BBC News|website=BBC|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/story/victims-angry-at-blood-inquiry-whitewash-10366299|title=Victims Angry At Blood Inquiry 'Whitewash'|newspaper=Sky News|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref name=whe>{{Cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/603273/Six-year-inquiry-failed-find-full-awful-truth-scandal-tainted-blood|title=Six-year inquiry 'failed to find full awful truth about scandal of tainted blood'|last=Wheeler|first=Caroline|date=2015-09-06|newspaper=Express.co.uk|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref>

Professor John Cash who was a former director of the [[Scottish National Blood Transfusion Service]] said the executives responsible were able to avoid giving evidence. \Did Lord Penrose get to speak to the people with the real answers? No
column4: \" \"He tried but through no fault of his own he couldn’t get to the truth. He ran into serious problems because the Inquiries Act meant there was a whole area he could not address\".<ref name=whe/>

column1: Five deaths were examined as outlined in the inquiry's terms of reference
column4: Mrs Eileen O'Hara
column5: Alexander Black Laing
column6: Neil Mullen and Victor Tamburrini.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.penroseinquiry.org.uk/terms-of-reference/|title=Terms of Reference|website=www.penroseinquiry.org.uk|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref> Out of these 5 cases
column7: only 1 of the victims was a Haemophiliac. The 1 haemophilia case was a Hepatitis C infection that occurred in the 1960s
column8: before Factor concentrates were in use
column9: meaning that the case did not relate to the relevant period which is regarded at the mid-1970s–1980's.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2002/dec/17/bse.society|title=A bloody mess|date=2002-12-17|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref> None of these examined cases involved HIV infection.<ref>{{Citation|last=Tainted Blood|title=The Penrose Inquiry / Chairman's Statement - 25th March 2015|date=2015-03-26|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_itTVmzdVTk|accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref>

column1: Following the publication of the Penrose Inquiry
column2: [[David Cameron]] became the first British Prime Minister to offer a formal apology for the scandal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-32041715|title=Penrose inquiry: David Cameron apologises over infected blood|date=2015-03-25|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/health/prime-minister-david-cameron-apologises-8921356|title=Prime Minister David Cameron apologises over contaminated blood scandal|last=Williams|first=Tryst|date=2015-03-25|newspaper=walesonline|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=CampaignTB|title=Prime Minister's Questions : Formal Apology - Wednesday 25th March 2015|date=2015-03-31|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8EcXHg7utr4|accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref>

column1: [[Damages]] have never been paid before or after the inquiry to victims or their families in England or Scotland. Damages have been paid in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hepccomptrib.com/2016/index.php?page=1|title=Irish Hepatitis C Compensation Tribunal|website=www.hepccomptrib.com|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/29m-for-victim-of-blood-product-contamination-434458.html|title=€2.9m for victim of blood product contamination|date=2016-12-09|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mlaw.ie/solicitors-for/hep-c-a-hiv-compensation-tribunal.html|title=Hep C & HIV Compensation Tribunal - Malcomson Law Solicitors|last=Bannon|first=Ultan|website=www.mlaw.ie|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref>

column4:
{{Use British English|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{infobox military unit |unit_name=1st Indian Cavalry Division |image= |caption= |dates=September 1914 – March 1918 |country= [[British Raj|British India]] |allegiance= [[British Crown]] |branch= [[British Indian Army]] |type= [[Cavalry]] |role= |size= [[Division (military)|Division]] |command_structure= [[Indian Cavalry Corps]] |garrison= |garrison_label= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |colors_label= |march= |mascot= |equipment= |equipment_label= |battles=[[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] in [[World War I]] :[[Battle of Cambrai (1917)|Battle of Cambrai]] |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= |battle_honours_label= |disbanded= |flying_hours= |website= |commander1= |commander1_label= |commander2= |commander2_label= |commander3= |commander3_label= |commander4= |commander4_label= |notable_commanders=[[Henry Peregrine Leader]]
[[Michael Rimington]] |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label= |identification_symbol_2= |identification_symbol_2_label= |identification_symbol_3= |identification_symbol_3_label= |identification_symbol_4= |identification_symbol_4_label= }} The '''1st Indian Cavalry Division''' was a division of the [[British Indian Army]] which was formed at the outbreak of [[World War I]]. It served on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]], and was renamed the '''4th Cavalry Division''' on 26 November 1916.{{harvnb|Perry|1993|p=14}} In March 1918, the 4th Cavalry Division was broken up. The British units remained in France, and the Indian elements were sent to Egypt to help form the [[4th Cavalry Division (India)|1st Mounted Division]].{{harvnb|Perry|1993|p=16}} ==History== [[File:Gen. Remington, Sir Partab Singh, & the Rajah of Rutlam riding in France (Linghem). Photographer- H. D. Girdwood. (13874204213).jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|alt=Three men on horseback in front of other mounted men|Lt. Gen. [[Michael Rimington]], commander of the 1st Indian Cavalry Division and later of the [[Indian Cavalry Corps]], riding with [[Ratlam State|Ratlam maharaja]] Sajjan Singh and Sir [[Partab Singh]] in [[Linghem]], France, on 28 July 1915]] The division sailed for France from [[Bombay]] on 16 October 1914 under the command of Major General [[Hew Dalrymple Fanshawe|H. D. Fanshawe]]. The division was re-designated the 4th Cavalry Division in November 1916. During the war, they served in the trenches as infantry. The large number of early officer casualties affected the division's later performance. British officers who understood the language, customs, and psychology of their men could not be quickly replaced, and the alien environment of the Western Front affected the soldiers.{{harvnb|Haythornthwaite|1996}} The division served in France and Flanders, held in reserve for the expected breakthrough. It provided dismounted parties for trench duty, but its only battle was the [[Battle of Cambrai (1917)|Battle of Cambrai]] during the German counterattacks of 30 November – 3 December. In March 1918, the division was broken up and the Indian regiments were combined in Egypt with the [[Yeomanry Mounted Division]] to form the 1st Mounted Division (later the 4th Cavalry Division).{{cite web|title=Warpath |url=http://www.warpath.orbat.com/indian_cav/1_ind_cav_div.htm |accessdate=31 May 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080528042649/http://www.warpath.orbat.com/indian_cav/1_ind_cav_div.htm |archivedate=28 May 2008 |url-status=dead |df=dmy }} ==Order of battle== *[[2nd (Sialkot) Cavalry Brigade]]: ** [[17th Lancers]] ** [[6th King Edward's Own Cavalry]] ** [[19th Lancers]] ** [[Q Battery, Royal Horse Artillery]] ** 10th Machine Gun [[Squadron (army)|Squadron]] (joined after February 1916) *[[3rd (Ambala) Cavalry Brigade]] (left on 15 September 1915 for the [[2nd Indian Cavalry Division]]): ** [[8th (King's Royal Irish) Hussars]] ** [[9th Hodson's Horse]] ** [[30th Lancers (Gordon's Horse)]] ** [[A Battery, Royal Horse Artillery]] [[File:Comrades France (Photo 24-158).jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|alt=Horses and a large group of soldiers|English and Indian soldiers of the Lucknow Cavalry Brigade's Signal Troop relaxing in a farmyard at brigade headquarters, 28 July 1915]] *[[8th (Lucknow) Cavalry Brigade]]: ** [[1st King's Dragoon Guards]] (left on 7 October 1917) ** [[Queen's Own Yorkshire Dragoons]] (joined on 6 December 1917) ** [[29th Lancers (Deccan Horse)]] ** [[36th Jacob's Horse]] ** [[U Battery, Royal Horse Artillery]] ** 12th Machine Gun Squadron (from 29 February 1916) *[[5th (Mhow) Cavalry Brigade]] (joined on 15 September 1915 from the 2nd Indian Cavalry Division): ** [[6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons]] ** [[2nd Lancers (Gardner's Horse)]] ** [[Central India Horse]] ** [[A Battery, Royal Horse Artillery]] *[[XVI Brigade, Royal Horse Artillery]] (from 26 November 1916): ** A Battery, Royal Horse Artillery (with the 3rd (Ambala) Cavalry Brigade, then the 5th (Mhow) Cavalry Brigade) ** [[Q Battery, Royal Horse Artillery]] (with the 2nd [Sialkot] Cavalry Brigade) ** U Battery, Royal Horse Artillery (with the 8th [Lucknow] Cavalry Brigade) ** I Indian RHA Brigade Ammunition Column ==See also== {{portal|World War I}} * [[British cavalry during the First World War]] * [[List of Indian divisions in World War I]] Press | location = London | isbn = 1-85409-351-7 }} * {{cite book | ref = harv | last = Perry | first = F.W. | year = 1993 | title = Order of Battle of Divisions Part 5B. Indian Army Divisions | publisher = Ray Westlake Military Books | location = Newport | isbn = 1-871167-23-X }} * {{cite book | ref = harv | last = Preston | first = R.M.P. | year = 1921 | title = The Desert Mounted Corps: An Account of the Cavalry Operations in Palestine and Syria 1917–1918 | url = https://archive.org/details/desertmountedco00presgoog | publisher = Constable & Co. | location = London | oclc = 3900439 }} * {{cite book | ref = harv | last = Sumner | first = Ian | year = 2001 | title = The Indian Army 1914–1947 | publisher = Osprey Publishing | location = | isbn = 1-84176-196-6 }} *{{cite book |chapter=The Palestine Campaigns |last=Wavell |first=Field Marshal Earl|authorlink=Archibald Wavell, 1st Earl Wavell|editor-last=Sheppard|editor-first=Eric William |edition=4th |title=A Short History of the British Army |year=1968|origyear=1933|publisher=Constable & Co. |location=London|oclc=35621223}} ==External links== * {{cite web | url=http://www.1914-1918.net/1cavdiv_indian.htm | title=The 1st Indian Cavalry Division in 1914-1918 | last=Baker | first=Chris | publisher=The Long Long Trail | accessdate=19 July 2015 }} *{{cite web|url=http://www.warpath.orbat.com/indian_cav/1_ind_cav_div.htm |title=1st Indian Cavalry Division on ''The Regimental Warpath 1914 - 1918'' by PB Chappell |accessdate=2008-05-28 |url-status= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517085204/http://www.warpath.orbat.com/indian_cav/1_ind_cav_div.htm |archivedate=17 May 2008 |df=dmy }} {{Indian Divisions in World War I}} {{Indian Expeditionary Forces}} {{DEFAULTSORT:C1}} [[Category:British Indian Army divisions]] [[Category:Indian World War I divisions]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1914]] [[Category:Military units and formations disestablished in 1918]] [[Category:British cavalry divisions]]

'''EuroAtlantic Airways''', legally ''EuroAtlantic Airways – Transportes Aéreos S.A.'', is a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[airline]] specialized in [[leasing]] and [[air charter]] headquartered in [[Sintra]] and based at [[Lisbon Airport]].<ref name=\FI\">{{cite news | title= Directory: World Airlines | work= [[Flight International]] | page= 78 | date= 2007-04-03}}</ref>

column2: the company adopted the trade name ''Air Madeira'' until 17 May 2000
column3: when the [[Memorandum of Association]] was altered by deed
column4: and the name of EuroAtlantic Airways – Transportes Aéreos S.A. was adopted. EuroAtlantic also took over the [[corporate design]] from Air Zarco which is still used today. The airline was founded by Portuguese businessman Tomaz Metello
column5: who was the owner of the airline until 2019. It was sold to the Luxembourg group Imperial Jet
column6: led by German-Lebanese pilot and businessman Abed El-Jaouni.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.flightglobal.com/airlines/investment-firm-i-jet-acquires-euroatlantic/135591.article|title=Investment firm I-Jet acquires EuroAtlantic|last=Gubisch2019-11-29T10:47:00+00:00|first=Michael|website=Flight Global|language=en|access-date=2019-12-22}}</ref> EuroAtlantic also owns 38% of the national airline of [[São Tomé and Príncipe]]
column7: [[STP Airways]].

column1: EuroAtlantic operated a direct flight from Lisbon to [[Dili]]'s [[Presidente Nicolau Lobato International Airport]] in January 2008 using a [[Boeing 767]] carrying 140 members of the Portuguese National Guard.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.euroatlantic.pt/downloads/en_29_01_2008.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-03-30 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320171502/http://www.euroatlantic.pt/downloads/en_29_01_2008.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-20 }}</ref> It was the first aircraft larger than a [[Boeing 737]] to ever land at the airport.

EuroAtlantic was known for operating the last [[Lockheed L-1011 TriStar]] in passenger service in Europe. It was phased out in March 2010 and is since stored at [[Amman Civil Airport]].<ref>http://www.airfleets.net/ficheapp/plane-l10-1240.htm</ref>

column2: euroAtlantic ended its freighter operations by phasing out its sole [[Boeing 767-300F]] cargo aircraft.<ref>http://www.ch-aviation.com/portal/news/53571-portugals-euroatlantic-airways-ends-freighter-operations</ref>

column1: EuroAtlantic Airways operates worldwide charter services as well as [[Aircraft
column3: Maintenance and Insurance|ACMI]] and other [[wet lease]] operations
column4: mostly on behalf of other airlines. For example
column5: EuroAtlantic operated two [[Boeing 777]]s on behalf of [[Biman Bangladesh Airlines]] in 2009<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/search_index.php?page=image&image_id=6930|title=The financial express - First Financial Daily Newspaper in Bangladesh|work=thefinancialexpress-bd.com|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref> and two [[Boeing 767]]s for [[Air Canada]] in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Important information regarding our euroAtlantic Boeing 767-300ER|url=http://www.aircanada.com/en/travelinfo/airport/codeshare_yu.html|publisher=Air Canada|accessdate=May 21
column6: 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521183749/http://www.aircanada.com/en/travelinfo/airport/codeshare_yu.html|archivedate=May 21
column7: 2014}}</ref> Among their usual customers are airlines like [[TAP Air Portugal]]
column8: [[LOT Polish Airlines]]
column11: [[TUI fly Belgium|TUIFly]]

column1: EuroAtlantic Airways also operates a single scheduled route between Lisbon and [[Bissau]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flyeuroatlantic.pt/|title=Voos Directos Guiné Bissau a partir de Lisboa - Fly euroAtlantic|work=flyeuroatlantic.pt|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref>

column4: and the name of EuroAtlantic Airways – Transportes Aéreos S.A. was adopted. EuroAtlantic also took over the [[corporate design]] from Air Zarco which is still used today. The airline was founded by Portuguese businessman Tomaz Metello
column5: who was the owner of the airline until 2019. It was sold to the Luxembourg group Imperial Jet
column6: led by German-Lebanese pilot and businessman Abed El-Jaouni.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.flightglobal.com/airlines/investment-firm-i-jet-acquires-euroatlantic/135591.article|title=Investment firm I-Jet acquires EuroAtlantic|last=Gubisch2019-11-29T10:47:00+00:00|first=Michael|website=Flight Global|language=en|access-date=2019-12-22}}</ref> EuroAtlantic also owns 38% of the national airline of [[São Tomé and Príncipe]]
column7: [[STP Airways]].

column1: EuroAtlantic operated a direct flight from Lisbon to [[Dili]]'s [[Presidente Nicolau Lobato International Airport]] in January 2008 using a [[Boeing 767]] carrying 140 members of the Portuguese National Guard.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.euroatlantic.pt/downloads/en_29_01_2008.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-03-30 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320171502/http://www.euroatlantic.pt/downloads/en_29_01_2008.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-20 }}</ref> It was the first aircraft larger than a [[Boeing 737]] to ever land at the airport.

EuroAtlantic was known for operating the last [[Lockheed L-1011 TriStar]] in passenger service in Europe. It was phased out in March 2010 and is since stored at [[Amman Civil Airport]].<ref>http://www.airfleets.net/ficheapp/plane-l10-1240.htm</ref>

column2: euroAtlantic ended its freighter operations by phasing out its sole [[Boeing 767-300F]] cargo aircraft.<ref>http://www.ch-aviation.com/portal/news/53571-portugals-euroatlantic-airways-ends-freighter-operations</ref>
Global News (Canada) broadcast that a EuroAtlantic Airways Boeing 777 <ref>https://www.airfleets.net/ficheapp/plane-b777-28513.htm</ref>
column4: chartered by the Government of Canada to repatriate Canadian passengers left stranded by the [[coronavirus]] quarantine on the Grand Princess cruise ship off the coast of California
column5: had landed at CFB Trenton. Those people will spend an additional 14 days quarantined on the base due to the COVID-19 outbreak.<ref>https://globalnews.ca/news/6654104/coronavirus-grand-princess-evacuees-trenton/</ref> On 4 April 2020
column6: EuroAtlantic operated a Boeing 767-300ER chartered by the Portuguese government to repatriate 211 mainly Portuguese passengers from Dili
column7: East Timor
column8: to Lisbon; most were either teachers or military personnel.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mawarni |first1=Puspa |title=Covid-19. 220 portugueses partem de Timor-Leste este sábado |trans-title=Covid-19. 220 Portuguese leave East Timor this Saturday |url=https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2020-04-03-Covid-19.-220-portugueses-partem-de-Timor-Leste-este-sabado |accessdate=6 April 2020 |work=Expresso |agency=Lusa |date=3 April 2020 |language=pt}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Aleixo |first1=Mário |title=Covid-19. Portugueses chegaram de Timor-Leste tranquilos e aliviados |trans-title=Covid-19. Portuguese arrived from Timor-Leste calm and relieved |url=https://www.rtp.pt/noticias/pais/covid-19-portugueses-chegaram-de-timor-leste-tranquilos-e-aliviados_n1218442 |accessdate=6 April 2020 |work=RTP News |date=5 April 2020 |language=pt}}</ref>

column1: EuroAtlantic Airways operates worldwide charter services as well as [[Aircraft
column3: Maintenance and Insurance|ACMI]] and other [[wet lease]] operations
column4: mostly on behalf of other airlines. For example
column5: EuroAtlantic operated two [[Boeing 777]]s on behalf of [[Biman Bangladesh Airlines]] in 2009<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/search_index.php?page=image&image_id=6930|title=The financial express - First Financial Daily Newspaper in Bangladesh|work=thefinancialexpress-bd.com|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref> and two [[Boeing 767]]s for [[Air Canada]] in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Important information regarding our euroAtlantic Boeing 767-300ER|url=http://www.aircanada.com/en/travelinfo/airport/codeshare_yu.html|publisher=Air Canada|accessdate=May 21
column6: 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521183749/http://www.aircanada.com/en/travelinfo/airport/codeshare_yu.html|archivedate=May 21
column7: 2014}}</ref> Among their usual customers are airlines like [[TAP Air Portugal]]
column8: [[LOT Polish Airlines]]

South Korea | language = English, Korean | budget = | gross = }} '''''Ark''''' is a 2003{{cite web|title=Ark (2003) - Rotten Tomatoes|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1148278_ark|website=rottentomatoes.com|language=english|accessdate=6 October 2019}} American-South Korean [[animated]] [[science fiction film]] directed by [[Subro Adonis]], animated by [[John Woo|Digital Rim]]. It is the flagship project for both the director and the studio. Attempting to address the failures of ''[[Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within]]'', the film is an attempt to merge anime-style visuals with a faster, action-oriented plot more palatable to Western audiences. The film's plot features many [[archetype]]s taken from ''[[Final Fantasy]]''-style [[Japan]]ese [[console RPGs]]; a young male resistance fighter, a young girl with special powers who unknowingly is her planet's [[Messiah]], an evil \right-hand man\"
column5: and a small
column6: cute pet mascot. It is the spiritual successor to ''[[Elysium (2003)]]'' which takes place in the same universe as the film.<ref>{{cite web|title=ELYSIUM’S SPIRITUAL SUCCESSOR!|url=https://gatesmediablog.wordpress.com/2016/12/29/elysiums-spiritual-successor|language=english|accessdate=5 March 2020}}</ref> {{Citation needed|date=August 2008}}

column1: ''Ark'' takes place on a dying alien world in which a global war between two technologically advanced human civilizations has reduced the planet to a wasteland. The only way to escape the world is by activating the Ark
column2: an ancient giant robot capable of supporting a human city as well as traveling through space.
the military general of the reigning civilization
column4: who captured the Ark from the Ceveans. But they are unable to get the Ark to work in order to save their people. The Ceveans
column5: having been enslaved and with only the wasteland to roam free are constantly attacked and brutalised by the Storrians. A leader of their resistance movement is a young resistance fighter named Rogan. Rogan is arrested during a resistance uprising
column6: but manages to escape. He bumps into the general's adopted daughter Amarinth
column7: whom the general had secretly rescued from a Cevean hibernation pod cluster where they had hidden their children for safety. They then meet again during a civilian protest rally and she offers to help hide him and tend to his wounds. Rogan goes with her back to her apartment and meets her pet JuJu
column8: but then vanishes when he discovers she's the Storrian general's daughter.

column3: arrives unexpectedly to take Amarinth into custody after discovering the truth of her lineage. Rogan helps her escape from Baramanda and takes her to the resistance base within the slave quarters of the Ark. There she meets with an elderly man who explains Amarinth's birthright with the help of JuJu
column4: who turns out to have originally belonged to him. Unknown to Rogan
column5: and to Amarinth herself
column6: she turns out to be the daughter of the Cevean priestess who originally built the Ark
column7: Amiel
column8: who had disappeared 100 years earlier.

column1: Amiel helped construct not just the Ark the Storrians hold
column2: but another known as The Ark of York. The plans for the Arks passed down from the Gods (another alien race). It took all her strength to create them
column3: causing her to fall into a deep sleep and not awaken again. Before entering her eternal hibernation
column4: she placed her very young daughter into the hidden hibernation pod. Then her body was secretly hidden by her people until discovered by the Storrians.

column1: They find Amiel's molecular structure enables her body to generate a pulsing electronic field throughout her bloodstream. Not only does this make her body perfectly preserved despite how long she had been inactive
column2: it is the reason the Arks will not work: she and Amarinth are descendants of the gods themselves and only they have the ability to pilot the Arks. A cell of her dead blood can supply power to an entire building
column3: but it becomes apparent that no matter how much energy Amiel's body retains
column4: since she is dead it's not enough to move the ark.

column1: Both civilizations scramble to use Amiel's daughter
column3: to activate their Ark and leave the other civilization behind to die. However
column4: Amarinth
column5: who has ties to both civilizations
column6: wishes to try to find a way to use her power to save everyone. She is opposed by the lifeforce-stealing wraith Baramanda
column7: who wishes to steal the power of the Ark for his own selfish purposes.

column1: Amarinth after going to the Ark of York
column2: refuses to pilot it and leave the Storrians behind. Despite her lineage as a Cevean
column3: she was raised as a Storrian. When she finds out her father
column4: Jallak
column5: had been arrested for high treason and was to be executed for hiding her
column6: she demands that Rogan and the others help her rescue him if they want her help. They agree and return to save him.

column2: Baramunda tries to drain Amarith's blood but is stopped by Amiel who awakens momentarily to stop him. All escape but Jallak remains behind to save his people
column3: as the Ark starts to fall apart. Rogan takes Amarinth back to The Ark of York as Baramanda merges with the core of the other Ark and awakens it. Amarinth discovers that
column4: just as her mother Amiel died in constructing the Arks
column5: so she would perish to pilot one. Rogan and Amarinth kiss for the first and final time as she merges with the core of York just as The Ark comes stomping up to it. The Arks clash in a giant battle with the earth breaking down beneath their feet. Amarinth grabs the city plate off of SidArk as Jallak and his friend set the self-destruct mechanism. They perish in the explosion as the planet begins to crumble.

column1: Rogan narrates at the end as it shows The Ark of York kneeling with the SidArk city plate on another planet flourishing with vegetation. He states that no one knew both civilizations would make it and neither does anyone think it would work out
column3: sharing the planet. He continues saying that it was hard to imagine that their old world
column4: which was now no more
column5: might have looked like this before the war. So the Storrians and Ceveans are going to try to coexist
column6: to preserve this planet and Amarinth's sacrifice. It's difficult at times
column7: and Rogan wishes that Amarinth was there to bridge the gap between the two civilizations. He states that they could have learned so much from her
column8: but that they already had.

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Use British English|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = [[The Right Honourable]] | name = Sir Dawson Bates, Bt | honorific-suffix = {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|OBE|PC|JP|DL}} | image = File:Northern Ireland Cabinet 1921.jpg | caption = Bates (on left) in 1921 | birth_date =23 November 1876 | birth_place = [[Belfast]], United Kingdom | death_date =20 June 1949 | death_place = [[Glastonbury]], United Kingdom | party = [[Ulster Unionist Party]] | spouse = Jessie Muriel Cleland | children = 1 | religion = [[Church of Ireland]] | office = [[Minister of Home Affairs (Northern Ireland)|Minister of Home Affairs]] | term_start=7 June 1921|term_end=6 May 1943 | constituency_MP2= [[Belfast East (Northern Ireland Parliament constituency)|Belfast East]]
[[Belfast Victoria (Northern Ireland Parliament constituency)|Belfast, Victoria]] (1929–1945) | parliament2 =Northern Ireland | term_start2 = 1921 | term_end2 = 1945 }} '''Sir Richard Dawson Bates, 1st Baronet''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|OBE|PC|JP|DL}} (23 November 1876 – 10 June 1949), known as '''Dawson Bates''', was an [[Ulster Unionist Party]] member of the [[Northern Ireland House of Commons]]. He was born in [[Strandtown]], [[Belfast]], the son of Richard Dawson Bates, solicitor and Clerk of the Crown, and Mary Dill. His paternal grandfather, John Bates (d. 1855), had been a minor figure in the Conservative Party in Belfast, before his duties were discharged on a Chancery Court ruling of maladministration. Bates was educated at [[Coleraine Academical Institution]]. After studying at [[Queen's College, Belfast]], became a [[solicitor]] in 1900, in 1908 founding a firm with his uncle – E and R.D. Bates, later R.B.Uprichard would be apprenticed, become a partner and eventually take over the firm of E and R.D. Bates and Uprichard, as Crown Solicitor. In 1906, Bates was appointed Secretary of the Ulster Unionist Council. During this time, he was instrumental in the events of [[Ulster Day]] and in the formation of the [[Ulster Volunteers|UVF]], organised the [[Larne gun-running]] and supported the formation of the [[Ulster Unionist Labour Association]] to counter [[socialism]].\"Bates
column5: Sir (Richard) Dawson\"
column6: ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]''</ref>  He toured Northern Ireland
column7: working hard to build up the Unionist Party
column8: while portraying all [[Roman Catholic]]s
column9: thus Nationalists as traitors.<ref>John F. Harbinson
column12: p.51</ref> Bates heavy influence in the UUP meant his reluctance to co-operate with Roman Catholics had to be heeded if the party was to avoid splits.<ref name=\"Bates anti-Catholic views\">{{cite book |last1=Harbinson |first1=John |title=The Ulster Unionist Party 1882–1973 |publisher=Blackstaff Press |location=Belfast |page=51 |edition=1 }}</ref>

column1: Bates stood down as Secretary on his election to [[Parliament of Northern Ireland|Stormont]] in [[1921 Northern Ireland general election|1921]]
column2: where he represented first [[East Belfast (Assembly constituency)|East Belfast]] and later Belfast Victoria. In the government of [[Sir James Craig]] he was the first [[Minister for Home Affairs]] and a member of the [[Privy Council of Northern Ireland]].  He introduced the Civil Authorities (Special Powers) Act
column3: but opposed the [[Ulster Protestant Association]].  Under his administration
column4: he was accused of [[gerrymandering]]
column5: and of intervening to ensure that prison sentences were not imposed on Protestants who attacked Catholics.<ref name=\"odnb\" />

column1: Bates was also a Deputy Lord Lieutenant of [[County Down]].

column2: daughter of Sir Charles John Cleland.  They had one son
column4: 2nd Baronet (an Oxford-educated Wykehamist

column1: He was appointed an [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in the [[1919 New Year Honours]]
column2: <ref>{{London Gazette |issue=31114 |date=8 January 1919 |page=453 |supp=y}}</ref> [[Knight Bachelor]] in 1921<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=32243 |date=1 March 1921 |page=1692}}</ref> and was made a [[baronet]] of Magherabuoy
column4: in [[County Londonderry]] on 7 June 1937.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=34410 |date=22 June 1937 |page=4010}}</ref>  In his retirement strained financial circumstances and security (he constantly required a police escort) led him to  rent Butleigh House
column5: near [[Glastonbury]]
column6: [[Somerset]].  It was here he died in 1949; Sir Dawson's body was flown back to Ulster for burial at Ballywillan Church of Ireland.<ref name=\"odnb\" />

column1: Bates was a director and president of [[Glentoran F.C.|Glentoran Football Club]].<ref>Malcolm Brodie (1981)
column2: ''The Story of Glentoran''. Belfast:Glentoran Football Club

{{other people|Daniel Oliver}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}}

{{Infobox person
|name          = Daniel Oliver
|image_size = 
|caption = 
|birth_name    = Daniel Oliver
|birth_date    = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1939|03|10}}
|birth_place   = [[New York City]], United States
|occupation    = Lawyer, writer, editor
}}

'''Daniel Oliver''' (born March 10, 1939) is a former executive editor of ''[[National Review]]'' from 1973 to 1976 and chairman of the [[Federal Trade Commission]] from 1986 to 1990.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://reaganlibrary.archives.gov/archives/speeches/1986/71686f.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=May 20, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118042101/https://reaganlibrary.archives.gov/archives/speeches/1986/71686f.htm |archive-date=January 18, 2017 |url-status=dead }}</ref>  He was chairman of the ''National Review'' board and a trustee of the magazine made so by [[William F. Buckley, Jr.]], founder of the publication.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/29/us/national-review-founder-says-it-s-time-to-leave-stage.html</ref>

==Background==

Oliver grew up in New York City.  He graduated from Harvard College [1964] and Fordham Law School.<ref>http://www.independent.org/aboutus/person_detail.asp?id=1636</ref>

==Early career==

From 1959 to 1962, Oliver served in the US. Army, stationed in California and Germany.

In 1965, he was a candidate for New York's state assembly while campaigning with William F. Buckley, Jr., in his New York City mayoral race.

In 1970, he worked as the Director of Research for [[James L. Buckley]]'s  successful New York senatorial race.<ref>http://www.thecandidamerican.com/?page_id=258</ref>

==Reagan Administration==

Oliver was the General Counsel at the Department of Education from 1981 to 1983 under President Ronald Reagan.  He was General Counsel of the Department of Agriculture from 1983 to 1986 before becoming the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, a position he held until 1990.  He has an honorary doctoral degree from the Universidad Francisco Marroquin, an honor also bestowed upon former U.S. Ambassador [[Jeane Kirkpatrick]] and former Czech President [[Václav Klaus|Vaclav Klaus]].<ref>https://www.ufm.edu/index.php/Honorary_Doctoral_Degrees</ref>

The Oliver-run Federal Trade Commission was known as one of the most anti-cartelist in the nation's history.<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1987/04/27/daniel-oliver/d53bb117-8327-4de8-bcff-265ad9ee8093</ref>

=== Milk Cartel Battle ===

One of Oliver's more famous battles took place from 1986 to 1987 when he led the fight to deregulate the price of milk in New York.

He awarded a “National Consumer Fleece Award” to New York State Agriculture Commissioner Joseph Gerace for his support of the New York Milk Cartel which prevented a New Jersey dairy from selling milk in parts of New York City.  After Oliver, on the steps of City Hall at Christmas time, said Gerace had “brazenly upheld one of the most anti-consumer monopolies in the country” Oliver wished the Commissioner a “Fleece Navidad.”<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1986/12/23/fleecing-new-york-milk-consumers/7cece632-c729-4267-a6f7-413cc9adacdf</ref> The quip garnered Oliver headlines nationwide, and shortly afterwards the state’s support for the dairy cartel collapsed, and Gerach resigned under pressure from the Cuomo administration.

=== Health Insurance Cartel Battle ===

Oliver tried to repeal the insurance anti-trust exemption in health insurance markets in 1987, provoking a long and costly battle that he ultimately lost.<ref>https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=892&dat=19870626&id=E_NSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hoIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5493,6480102&hl=en</ref>  Oliver's goal was to reduce the costs of American health insurance by removing barriers limiting competition—in this case, being the first FTC chairman to propose the destruction of the [[McCarran–Ferguson Act|McCarran-Ferguson Act]].  However, the issue has again received national attention in the 2016 presidential election.<ref>http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/election/article63786822.html</ref>

=== Airline Competition Policy ===

Oliver defended airline deregulation in the 1980s and said it had allowed for more companies to enter the market and lower overall prices—saving Americans $100 billion.<ref>https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2519&dat=19880209&id=LpZiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=63cNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4756,1179403&hl=en</ref>

=== \The Oliver Effect\" ===

column1: Oliver's tenure at the FTC led some analysts to saying he sought to implement \"The Oliver Effect\" in product markets.<ref>\"Competition produces better products at lower costs. Regulations have made the health insurance markets of our states no different from the New York City milk market before chairman Oliver came along. Who but an ideologue can doubt lifting those restrictive regulations can produce the Oliver Effect in health insurance costs
column4: July 9
column5: 2012</ref>  In this way
column6: Oliver also argued against foreign trade restrictions
column7: saying in 1986 that they cost Americans $50 billion a year.<ref>https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1310&dat=19870214&id=B61QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fOEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6641

column4: one of the founders of the modern conservative movement in America.

column4: Ricochet
column5: The American Conservative
column6: and The Washington Times.

He is married to Louise V. Oliver

column1: In June 2014 the band announced that they would cease performing and recording in October 2014 after their \"Last Hurrah\" tour.
Jim Jones has since been leading [[Jim Jones and The Righteous Mind]].
[[File:The Jim Jones Revue @ Sir Stewart Bovell Park (7 1 12) (6693048281).jpg|thumb|Jim Jones fronting the band at their performance at the 2012 [[Southbound Festival]].]]

Their style has been compared to early [[rock and roll]] artists [[Little Richard]] and [[Jerry Lee Lewis]]<ref name=\"Hann\">{{Cite news |last=Hann |first=Michael |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/aug/26/jim-jones-revue-burning-your-house-down-cd-review |title=The Jim Jones Revue: Burning Your House Down |date=26 August 2010 |work=The Guardian |access-date=27 August 2010  |issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref name=\"Hughes\">{{Cite news |last=Hughes |first=Rob |url=http://archive.classicrockmagazine.com/view/september-2010/66/the-jim-jones-revue |title=The Jim Jones Revue: Burning Your House Down |date=September 2010 |work=[[Classic Rock (magazine)|Classic Rock]] |url-status=dead |issue=123 |page=66}}</ref> as well as to [[punk rock]] bands such as [[The Stooges]]
column2: [[MC5]] and [[Motörhead]].<ref name=\"Hughes\" /><ref name=\"Jelbert\">{{Cite news |last=Jelbert |first=Steve |url=https://thequietus.com/articles/03255-jim-jones-revue-here-to-save-your-soul-album-review |title=Jim Jones Revue |date=18 November 2009 |work=The Quietus |access-date=27 August 2010 }}</ref>

column3: blustery rhythm\" meant that \"you’re bombarded with sonic viscera\".<ref name=\"Sharp\">{{Cite news |last=Sharp |first=Johnny |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/9gx2/ |title=Review of The Jim Jones Revue – Burning Your House Down |year=2010 |work=BBC Music |access-date=3 September 2010 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

column4: much louder
column5: and wildly more distorted\".<ref name=\"Hann\" />
